11.content:
The wolf padded down the streets, looking this way, and that way. Those that noticed him kept walking, unless they wished to know more about a wolf's mouth than they wanted to otherwise know. Around the wolf's neck was a collar, and an object dangled from it. The object was made of copper and bronze, with a sliver of silver for the shine, and gold for the color, meaning it was worthless, financially, but it was important to those that had it.

At the end of the street, a rookie guard watched the wolf. They wanted to cry out, but the wolf looked right at them, and any thought of calling out vanished. The wolf came right up to them, tilted their head slightly, and stepped into the shadows behind them.

A moment later, a slightly gruff voice called out. "You do have a spare pair of trousers and a shirt in your pack. I need them."

The guard gulped, as they carefully took their pack off, and set it on the ground. They watched as a hairy arm grabbed it, and dragged it back. They heard the pack being open, and things being took out. A while later, the pack was set next to them.

"You may turn around now."

The guard carefully turned, and found themself looking at their Commander, who now looked human.

"Do you smoke?" the Commander asked.

The guard gulped. "No Sir." Their voice sounded off somewhat. "Father always told me it was a filthy habit."

The Commander chuckled. "And he was right; messes with your sense of smell. Maybe an average human's nose is not as good as a werewolf's, but it can pick up things like smoke, dung, food, cologne, and of course, perfume."

The guard gulped at this last bit. "Perfume? I don't smell any."

The Commander looked right at the guard. "You haven't worn it in the last three days, you cut your hair right about then, and your socks smell like you've been missing the can in the Privy. You're a woman pretending to be a man, right?"

The guard hung their head. "Yes, Sir." Their voice sounded like it was defeated. "I was told you didn't hire human women."

The Commander chuckled. "Whoever told you that pile of hogwash is full of horse apples. I hire anyone whom I think will get the job done. I know you signed up as John Smith, but what's your real name?"

"Sally Butcher," the woman said. "Father said that he wanted me to marry a rich man, but I didn't want that."

"I hear you there," the Commander said. "Rich people are never fun. Personally, I hate mingling with them, but given my position, it's inevitable that I have to lower myself to their level." He looked at her. "Sally, I don't care what your family story is. I don't care about your race, or your species, or your status before you became a guard. All I care about is that you are a Guard, right here, right now. Understand?"

The guard smiled, and nodded. "Yes Sir."

"Good," the Commander said. "When your shift is over, I expect you get things straightened with the Quartermaster; we already have ten John Smiths, and having one of them really being a Sally Butcher would be a relief to him on Pay Day."

"I understand sir."

"Good. Mind turning around; I don't want my guards to see their Commander strip naked in front of them."

Sally turned, and she watched as first a shirt, and then the trousers landed on her pack. Then she watched as a wolf emerged from the shadows. The wolf looked at her, and she swore she saw it wink at her, before resuming walking.

Rutabaga Blackfur Copperfindersson remained in his wolf form as he patrolled the streets. Occasionally he saw a guard, who gave him some sort of sign of recognition, and sometimes he saw a thief, who would carefully pull their hands from someone else's pocket, and pretend that nothing was going on. Things were going good so far.

Now, the real question was where to go next....

113.content:
Rutabaga gave himself a silent chuckle, as he decided to head home.

Padding down an area filled with homes of the Wealthy and Nobility, most homes had, basically, a Private Guard, who would do what the homeowner told them to do, although most had learned why it was a bad idea to interfere in City Guard business, and Rutabaga's rank as, as much as he hated to say it, a Knight, and a Baron, tended to open doors that the feet of trolls and golems would otherwise break down. After all, being polite to a Noble was cheap, whereas doors cost money, and kept the carpet from getting dirty.

Soon, Rutabaga came to a home which had a rather nice yard, and garden, not to mention a small forest, filled with plenty of game for him to hunt, although it needed fresh stock every so often. There was no gate on the pathway, although there was a "Beware of Dog" sign, which he always chuckled at, when he was human. He walked up to the door, and stopped before it. He sniffed, and caught a scent around the doggy-door. With a silent laugh, he went through the door, and shifted into his human form. He walked over to the robe rack, took one off, and quickly turned around, tossed the robe at the black figure that had tried to sneak up on him, and shoved them up against the wall.

"Hold still," he said, forcing his fingers into the figure's mouth. He soon pulled out a vial, and looked at it. He looked at the person. "This isn't the usual stuff you guys carry when you try to kill me."

"It's aniseed oil," the figure said, in a young woman's voice. "I came here for a test, to see if I could get close enough to do the deed."

"This would have stuffed my nose up for a week. Dry run, or Guild exam?" Rutabaga asked.

"Guild exam," the figure said.

Rutabaga chuckled. He then carefully removed the cloth that hid all but the person's eyes and mouth, revealing a rather lovely face. "Well, you'd put a smile on someone as they died."

The person chuckled nervously. "I say it's a curse. No one takes me seriously."

"I can understand that," Rutabaga said, as he carefully started to disarm, and in the process, disrobe, the woman. "That being said, you do know the guild rules are that, if you fail, you have to suffer the penalty; you failed to hit me with this, so, I get to punish you."

"Do you think that you could do it another time?" the woman asked. "I'm going to get married next month, and I've been saving myself for my husband-to-be."

Rutabaga chuckled. "I'd love to, but as you know, I have a reputation to uphold." He lifted her hand, and looked at her ring. "Who is the husband-to-be?"

"Lord Greasy Bum, son of Lord Wet Bum."

"Unfortunate family name, but a very good family, with plenty of money, and they donate to the hospital," said Rutabaga. He looked at the woman. "You look familiar; any relation to Ripper Blood?"

The woman grinned. "That's my uncle."

"I remember him; he had some rather unique knives," said Rutabaga. "Smashed his nose and broke his left leg. That means that you're the daughter of Cyan Blood; she tried to poison me."

"It's Cyan Tanner now," the woman said "I'm Slippery Tanner, soon to be Slippery Bum."

Rutabaga chuckled. "It's a small world; your mother and uncle both tried to kill me, and here you are coming after me for a Guild test. Now, I'm sure your mother told you what I did to her."

By this time, Slippery was disrobed, and, more embarrassingly, mostly disarmed. "Yes," Slippery said. "And I did prepare for that possibility; I have some Zonkiers in my robe."

Rutabaga grinned. "Nice try, but we'll use mine; I don't feel like scratching myself in Public too much, like what happened a few years back." He opened a drawer, and pulled out a small packet. "Always useful at preventing unwanted pregnancies." He then removed her hairpin, causing her hair to fall to her shoulders. Pressing a button, he saw a hypodermic needle come out of the end of the hairpin. "Good way to keep me from moving." He tossed it to the floor, along with her other weapons, and clothes. "Now, there is a question I have to ask you....."
113.title: Dealing with a Female Assassin

1131.content:
"So, just how old are you?" Rutabaga asked.

"I'm of Legal Age," said Slippery. "I'm seventeen going on eighteen."

Rutabaga raised an eyebrow. "When will you be eighteen?"

"In an hour."

"You were born at midnight?"

"12:07 actually, but midnight sounds more dramatic."

"Seven minutes can make a difference between you being a licensed Assassin and a young killer," said Rutabaga. "You know the Assassins Guild has rules about that sort of stuff."

"Yes, but since it was my birthday, they made a slight exception," said Slippery.

"I see," said Rutabaga. "And since I don't kill Licensed Assassins, your teachers figured I'd be a safe enough target for you to go after, in case you failed."

Slippery chuckled nervously. "Something like that."

"Good to know," said Rutabaga. "Um, another question: you wouldn't happen to be carrying a Slimmer Blade by any chance?"

Slippery blushed. "I haven't gotten one of those yet; it isn't seemly for an Assassin to have that blade."

Rutabaga chuckled, opened another drawer, and pulled out a blade that was, at most, the length of a woman's palm, and half as wide as a finger. "There are plenty of women who claim that these are more effective at preventing unwanted pregnancies than even a Zonkier, especially if the sex is unwanted. After all, the touch of cold metal has been proven to instantly halt a man's sex drive. There are plenty of Ladies of Negotiable Affection, and seamstresses, and others, who swear by them, and never leave home without their Slimmer Blades."

"That sounds like some sort of advertisement," said Slippery.

Rutabaga looked at the very narrow blade. "Actually, it's written on the blade itself. See the very small print?"

"Wow! They really etch that in all of these blades?" Slippery asked.

"Every one I've bought anyways," said Rutabaga. "I issue them to my female guards, and I recommend that they take classes from Madam Sally She's A Big One Rose, which reminds me - I'd best get one for Butcher, and have her take those classes." He looked at Slippery. "I don't have any personal experience myself, but I'm told they're very comfortable, and no one else even knows that they are even there, until they find out the hard way."

"You know that most Unlicensed Thieves don't bother an Assassin," said Slippery.

"I'm not talking about those guys," said Rutabaga. "There's always that someone who sees a pretty woman, and decides to force himself on her; especially if you decide to not be wearing black on that day."

"You have a point there," said Slippery.

"Good," said Rutabaga. "Now, would you mind getting dressed; I'm going to help you celebrate your birthday."

He handed her the blade.

Slippery looked at the blade, and looked at him. "Celebrate my birthday?"

"Can't take you out for failing an exam, but I can take you out for your birthday."

Slippery looked at the blade again. "Um, I don't know how to wear this."

Rutabaga smiled. "I guess I'll show you." He pressed his body against hers, accepted the blade, lowered his hand, and placed it by the inside of her legs. "First things first; handle goes up, and the tip points down." He then gave her a slow, and gentle, kiss.



A while later, Slippery finished wrapping the cloth around her face. "You're right; I can hardly feel it."

Rutabaga chuckled. "Removing it is just as simple too; there's always a reason a Lady of Negotiable Affection has their client wait a bit before they commence to business, that being one of them. Plus, it helps to get them ready for the next part."

Slippery chuckled nervously. "I can imagine how."

Rutabaga grinned. "So, have you ever eaten at a dwarf restaurant?"

"Um, I can't say that I have," said Slippery.

"I know of a place that serves some very excellent rat; grilled, roasted, poached, broiled, or burnt in a fire and covered in ketchup." He then close his eyes and smiled. "Of course, none of their cooking comes close to father's Rat and Crow Stew: A minimum of one rat, a minimum of one crow, followed by as much garlic, onions, leeks, carrots, and potatoes as you want, plus whatever spices you wish to add. He always added curry to his, along with a pinch of salt and pepper."

"I see you have some fond memories of him," said Slippery.

"The only time I've ever seriously seen him upset was at my nineteenth birthday party; someone had delivered a cake, a very large one might I add, and since it was for me, I decided to have the first slice. Thing was, it was one of those pop-out cakes, and out jumped a woman dressed in black, and armed with two swords. Problem for her was this; I thought that she was part of the party, and was a Lady of Negotiable Affection that my parents had hired to pretend to be an Assassin coming to claim my virginity. She soon found herself without any clothes, or weapons, and I was enjoying her. Needless to say, she was quite embarrassed at having not only been foiled by her mark, but of the fact that the mark decided to have sex with her."

"Yes, Lady Two-Swords Too Sharp Blades told me about that," said Slippery. "And every time after that, any time a female assassin went after you, you had sex with them."

"Saves me the expense of hiring a Lady of Negotiable Affection," said Rutabaga. "That being said, I've never heard any real complaints from them, aside from being disarmed so thoroughly."

"So I've heard," said Slippery.

"Only real issue was the fact that me and her made a bit of a mess when we rolled into the cake, when I was trying to take her ninth knife out of her hands. She had thirty-seven of them strapped all over her body," said Rutabaga. "The Head Assassin had to laugh when she made her report to him over her failure; made refunding Lord Wonsin of his fee less painful. Of course, Lord Wonsin soon found out that mother didn't like someone targeting her son, all because I arrested his for being too rough with an off-duty Lady of Negotiable Affection."

"I heard about that to," said Slippery. "I've also heard other things about you as well."

"I'm sure most of them are slightly exaggerated," Rutabaga said, as he finished putting his own clothes on. He looked it over. He looked like most any other guard, save the collar around his neck, which had a badge that was rather plain, if shiny. "I'm glad I can wear this plain, and usable, outfit, as opposed to my Formal Outfit; I wish someone would set that horrible thing on fire." He grabbed the only thing of finery that set him apart from the other guards, a red cape with gold embroidering. Other officers might wear red capes, but none had the gold thread, and he was all right with just that detail. After all, the cape helped keep the rain off when need be.

He looked at Slippery. "I see you're dressed. Let's go."

11313.content:
As Rutabaga and Slippery walked down the streets, they passed plenty of City Guards.

"What's the matter?" one asked. "Did they lose a blade in a body?"

"If they did, it would be in our Lost and Found department," Rutabaga said, barely holding back a smile.

"Do I see some dark happenings going on?" another asked.

"Yes, and things will get very dark indeed for some." said Rutabaga.

"What trouble is this Assassin in that they need you with them?" a third asked.

"That would be with me."

The guard laughed at this.

"I've noticed that none of them have called you Commander, Baron Copperfindersson," said Slippery.

"Call me Rutabaga," said Rutabaga. "And drop the title and rank; I dislike them."

"It would be rude to be informal," said Slippery.

"Formal don't mean a thing when he chains you to the bed and is doing you doggy-style!" called out another guard.

Slippery chuckled nervously at this. "Do you really do that?"

Rutabaga grinned. "Would you like me to do you like that?"

"Um, no; the regular way will be fine," said Slippery. "No chains either."

"Good," said Rutabaga. "Chains make too much noise for my taste." Just then, his nose caught something, along with his ears. "Get down!" Pulling Slippery with him, Rutabaga glimpsed the crossbow bolt zip over them, and impale the guard that had just called out to them. "Slim! Are you alright?"

"Ugh! Just great! The bastard hit me right where it's going to show."

"Where?"

"My heart of course!" yelled Slim. "It would have been yours if you hadn't ducked."

Slippery looked at Rutabaga. "Let me guess; zombie?"

"Do you have a problem with that?" Slim yelled out. "Geesh! I have to pay for the patching on this thing too."

"Slim, mind walking over here?"

The guard came over.

"Turn around."

The guard turned, and Rutabaga got a good look at the bolt.

"A silver head," said Rutabaga. "That would have done the job, aside from piercing right through. This was meant for me."

"Um, do I get hazard pay for this?" Slim asked.

"No, but you can help me catch this guy," said Rutabaga.

"You'll have to get him before I do," said Slippery. "The Guild has an Automatic Contract on anyone that isn't an Assassin that tries to kill you, or doesn't hire an Assassin to kill you."

"Head Assassin respects me that much to protect me from Non-Assassin killers?" Rutabaga asked.

"No, but his wife does."

"Ah, she's the one that served me that frog soup with those rainbow-colored frogs; had a very interesting taste, which put a zip in it," said Rutabaga. "Ask her for some more of that stuff; I'm having a hard time finding the frogs she used, just leave out the Wolfbane - that gives me the runs, and I have a number of meetings to attend."

"I'll mention that to her," said Slippery. "You're the only person to ask for seconds from her, and thirds, and fourths, and fifths."

"It was very good frog soup," said Rutabaga. "Now, let's get this guy."

113131.content:
The cloaked figure ran across the rooftops. Every so often, they'd look down, and they'd see guards chasing after them; some were human, then there was the shorter dwarves, and the taller trolls and golems, who, while slow, could follow for a long time. He saw some large dogs, actually, werewolves in their wolf forms, outrunning the rest. Then there were the swarms of bats flying around - vampires.

He dropped onto a balcony, and was surprised to see a couple of other cloaked figures.

"What's the news?" one asked. "The Guards are stirred up about something."

"Someone tried to kill the Commander," he said. It was a safe enough statement.

The two figures looked at each other.

"That's going to be trouble," the one said.

"Especially if whomever it was wasn't a member of the Assassins Guild," said the other.

"What do you mean?" the person asked.

"You must be new to the area; are you affiliated with either the Assassins' Guild or the Thieves Guild?"

"Trying to get registered with them, but it's taking a while."

"Let's just say that the Head Assassin's wife has a thing for the Commander of the Guard; he's the only one to ever survive her cooking, and enjoyed it," the one Thief said. "If you aren't an Assassin when you try to kill him, or don't hire an Assassin to do the job, you get a Contract placed on your head."

"Yep," the other Thief said. "By now every Assassin has heard the call, and is off to collect the Contract."

"And the female Assassins will end up getting something else as well from the Commander," the first Thief said, nudging the other.

The second Thief chuckled. "I hear that; in fact, he'll be busy with one tonight - I was over by that area, and he caught a young one who is to die for, and - oh boy!"

"She that good looking?" the first Thief asked.

"That, and she was naked, as was he, and he was showing her how to wear a Slimmer Blade - needed to visit a Lady of Negotiable Affection to take care of something after that," the second Thief said.

The first Thief raised an eyebrow. "Good show?"

"Well, mainly he kissed her, but she was a young one, with all of her teeth, and no previous injuries from failures," the second Thief said.

The first Thief nodded. "I suppose that would make sense."

"Hey, where did that other guy go?" the second Thief asked.

The first Thief turned, and saw that the mysterious person had left. "Must of had important business."

"Well, let's hope that the Guards and Assassins catch that non-Assassin assassin," the second Thief said. "The streets aren't safe to rob folks on when those sorts of people are about."

"You know, I forgot to ask exactly whom he was trying to affiliate himself with," the first Thief said.

"Do you think he was an Unlicensed thief, or a non-Assassin assassin?" the second Thief asked.

"Best to let others know." The first Thief pulled out a whistle, and blew on it.



The figure kept running, and eventually decided he was too obvious on the rooftops, and climbed down the ladder on the side of a home, and dropped into an alley, and started to walk, when he noticed someone at the other end of the alley. "Could you step aside?"

"I could, but I won't," the person said.

"And why won't you?"

The person chuckled. "One, you tried to kill me. Two, you shot one of my guards, and you would have killed him if it wasn't for the fact that he's a zombie. Three, you are obviously not affiliated with the Assassins, who have the decency to try to do the job while I'm home to avoid harming the wrong people, which the Assassins frown upon. Fourth, I had to take my clothes off to pursue you in my wolf form, and unless you have a spare outfit, I don't want to be naked in Public - they might end up laughing at me. Of course, they'd laugh harder at you. Fifth, there's five Assassins waiting for you; unless you come with me, or another Guard, you will find yourself very dead, and it will be Legal. Of course, you're still going to hang; if Slim had been Human, you would have killed him, and you can't just get away with that sort of thing."

The figure tried to scale the wall of the home, when he dropped once more, dodging a crossbow bolt that was now embedded where his head had been.

"I told you; either you come with me and my Guards, or the Assassins kill you," the Commander said. "They don't like competition."


A while later, the would-be killer was being escorted by some Guards, and Rutabaga was wearing his uniform. "Thanks for the assist."

"You're welcome," said Slippery.

"You're good with the crossbow, and you made just enough noise to make him know something was wrong, forcing him to drop, just before you pulled the trigger," said Rutabaga.

"Well, it's not like it's 12:07 yet," said Slippery. "A test is one thing, but an actual killing, well, there might be issues."

"I'll see about putting in a good word with the Head Assassin, so that things are made official," said Rutabaga.

"Thanks," said Slippery.

"Now, let's go celebrate your birthday," said Rutabaga.

"Tell me; just how good is dwarf cooking?" Slippery asked.

Rutabaga chuckled. "I'll be honest; it helps if you were raised on it to truly appreciate it. Now, come on."

1131311.content:
A while later, Slippery was eating a rat leg that had been soaked in a Lemon and Garlic sauce. "This is really good."

"You're talking about the sauce, right?" Rutabaga asked.

"Well, the meat's pretty good too," said Slippery. "I mean, it doesn't taste like they caught it in an alley or something."

Rutabaga grinned. "Only lower-end places do that. Most hire special rat catchers to catch their supply, but these guys raise theirs on a farm, and feed their rats some really good food, which affects the flavor. Of course, the taste doesn't compare to a wild rat from the fields and such; very little fat on those, if any, but your average person isn't going to want to eat it. That's why they come up with these fancy names like Le Rat Recouvert de Saveur de Citron et D'ail, which means The Rat Covered in Lemon and Garlic Flavoring - give something a foreign sounding name, and folks will pay money to eat it."

"Like that one place that serves boiled boot leather, yet everyone there speaks like they're from Florance, even though they are really from around here?" Slippery asked.

Rutabaga grinned. "They know how to make some really good boiled boot leather. The Tyrant is planning on holding a big meeting there next week."

Slippery smiled. "I see. By the way, there is something I want to ask you."

"What would that be?"

11313111.content:
"Are you really the lost heir to the Big Fat Pig City throne?" Slippery asked.

Rutabaga chuckled. "That old rumor again? I doubt it."

"You know that the Assassins' Guild has a large library, and lots of diagrams of those they've killed over the years, and this has included a number of Royalty - Kings, Queens, Princes, Princesses, to say nothing about Bastards and Illegitimates. You share certain features with a number of the later ones, as does your father."

Rutabaga grinned. "It is well-known that the Royals had a habit of convincing women, and men, into their beds."

"Sounds familiar."

"But, while it is well-know that more than a few maids and serving wenches ended up carrying some Prince's illegitimate issue, some of which ended up taking the crown, what isn't well-known is that those women also had their own husbands that they had children with as well," said Rutabaga. "Maybe the reason I share some of the Royal features is because while I'm related to the Royal bloodline, but I'm really of the legitimate issue that the servant in question had with their lawful husband."

"I suppose that's one way of putting it," said Slippery. "Still, you could still be of the Royal bloodline."

Rutabaga grinned. "Given that there has been a number of Illegitimates and Bastards, lots of people could be of Royal blood, like the guy outside shoveling horse dung."

Slippery glanced out the window. "Possible, but it would be a ridiculous story - from Dung Shoveler to King." She looked at Rutabaga. "Finding out that the Commander of the Guards was secretly the King, now that would be a story."

"Have you ever asked why, if I really was the King, did I never ask for the throne?" Rutabaga asked.

"I never thought about that," said Slippery.

"It's very simple; it would be too confining," said Rutabaga. "As a Guard, I come and go as I please, I don't need to seek out a wife, although mother wishes that I find one, I'm not expected to have children, although mother wants grandkids, and no one bothers me, unless they have to."

"I see," said Slippery. "By the way...."

113131111.content:
"How did you know that I was at your place?" Slippery asked.

Rutabaga chuckled, and tapped his nose. "A wolf's nose is a lot better than that of a human. Also, your perfume was on the doggy door, and the female servants I have do not wear perfume of that quality, as they spend their money on more important things, like food."

"I didn't see them when I got there," said Slippery.

"One is on vacation, one is on honeymoon, one is sick with something, and the other is on the run with her husband's boyfriend," said Rutabaga.

"Really?" Slippery asked.

"Yes, but I suspect that the one claiming to be sick just wanted the day off." Rutabaga looked at Slippery. "That being said, your average human probably wouldn't have noticed the perfume on the doggy door, as they don't tend to use it. On the other hand, if they have a doggy door, they tend to have a dog, who might not like seeing someone else using their door."

Slippery gave a faint chuckle. "Could say the same about werewolves."

"Most are somewhat territorial," said Rutabaga. "Same with vampires. In the areas that they rule, bandits have to make deals in order to operate; forty percent of the loot goes to the local Count or Baron, roads must be maintained, travelers are not to be harmed, and they are to go after bandits that don't follow the rules. In short, they collect tolls, maintain the roads, and act as local law enforcement. After all, they don't want to incur the wrath of a werewolf or vampire."

"Yes, and it seems that it would be ill-advised to incur yours," said Slippery. "I heard about Lord Sorid; one of your guards was in a relationship with his daughter, and thus Lord Sorid had placed a Contract on him, or rather was in the process of doing so, when you showed up, and offered double the price that Lord Sorid had placed on your guard, for a Contract on Lord Sorid, which caused Lord Sorid to rethink his offer, and thus backed away from it."

"I don't like my guards getting killed," said Rutabaga.

It wasn't a good one, but it fooled the average eye at any rate.

He padded up to the figure, and whined. The figure turned, and he felt them look at him. Then the figure began to scratch his ears affectionately. Rutabaga leaned into them, as any dog would want to do. Whomever this woman was, she was good, and was smart enough to give pets enough affection to make them not bother her as she stole from their masters. Too bad for her, he wasn't a dog.

He looked up, and made sure that the badge on his collar was visible to the light. A gasp came from the thief. He could smell fear coming from her. She ran, and he pursued. It wasn't very far. It wasn't even five paces, and with him on her back, the thief wasn't moving.

A moment later, Rutabaga shifted into his human form, and took her outfit off, removing the magic that had hid her from human eyes. He grinned at what he saw.

"What do you want?" the woman asked.

"For you to return what you stole," said Rutabaga. "It's not yours."

"Why should I?" the woman asked. "It was to be stolen by the guild anyways."

"I already paid my fee," said Rutabaga.

The woman looked at him. "So, this was just a trap?"

Rutabaga nodded. "The Guild is waiting for me to bring you out. I'm sure you know what they do to unlicensed thieves."

"They wouldn't let me join their stupid Guild," the woman said. "Them and their stupid rules."

"I think if you ask nicely, and offer to show them where their gold is, they might be willing to let you join," said Rutabaga.

"They won't," said the woman. "I tried before."

"Why?" Rutabaga asked. "I know who your father is, just by your scent. I think he'd be very happy for you to join in the family tradition."

"That would be the problem," the woman said. "He doesn't know that I'm his daughter, and I don't want any favors from him either."

"Your father is-"

"Don't say it out loud," the woman said. "If his people are out there, I want no favors from them either. I want to join on my own merits."

"I see," said Rutabaga. "I've been there. You're afraid that you'd be placed in locations where your talents would be wasted because no one would want to upset your father."

"Yes," the woman said. "I'd have to reveal who my father is, as well as who my mother is."

"And just who is your mother?" Rutabaga asked.

"My mother is...."
1131311111131113311133312.title: The Scent of a Woman

choices: I'm going to take you to the Station.
I'm going to get the Head Thief. He needs to see you.
I'm just going to show you to my Guest Room and lock you in for the night.
11313111111311133111333122.content:
"My mother is the daughter of a Lord," the woman said.

"Ah," said Rutabaga. "I can see how that would complicate things."

"Problem is, she's also the daughter of a maid."

"Oh," said Rutabaga. "I can see where that could be a problem as well. You're the Illegitimate daughter of a Thief and woman, who is an Illegitimate daughter of a Lord and a maid."

"Yes, with no standing in the household that my grandmother worked at, and whom I'm related to," said the woman. "My mother took a job at the Thieves' Guild, where she met up with a Thief, who enjoyed a one-night thing with her, only to marry some rich woman instead of a lowly maid. I worked hard to perfect my skills. I made friends, including a young Mage who made me that enchanted robe. Thing is, I didn't even use it to plot my thefts - I just walked into the Head Thief's office, looked at the schedule, and I beat the Official Members to the punch. I should be a member, but that stupid rule. I'd have to tell who my father is, and I'd have to state my grandfather."

"Which worries you more?" Rutabaga asked. "The identity of your father, or your grandfather? I know that man's scent, for I've had dealings with him as well."

"My father is a good man, and all I want from him is that he recognize me as his, and maybe give my mother what she is owed, like an apology at any rate," the woman said. "As for my grandfather, he can die for all I care. My grandmother wasn't the only servant he used, and tossed out, and many weren't even willing."

"I know," said Rutabaga, as he put a robe on. "Had an issue with him last week over a young servant woman, who was taken to the Healers with injuries that were 'sustained while falling down the stairs' only it was quite clear that stairs were not involved in any shape or form, and it seemed she suffered from a miscarriage as well."

"Did you arrest him?" the woman asked.

"He had enough money to walk out of the station within the hour," said Rutabaga. "That and the woman claimed that 'It was just an accident', and told the guards I assigned to the case to just drop it. I told them to keep on it, and I assigned someone else to the case, whom she doesn't know about."

"Why did you do that?" the woman asked.

"A few accidents over several years I don't mind," said Rutabaga. "Over a dozen in a year, I find that to be suspicious, especially when one of them involves a pregnant woman."

"So, what happens now?" the woman asked.

"Well, I did just catch you trying to illegally rob my home, so......"
11313111111311133111333122.title: An Illegitimate Granddaughter of a Lord

113131111113111331113331222.content:
"I'm going to tell those guys outside to get the Head Thief," said Rutabaga. "He needs to know about you."

"No," the woman said. "I don't want anything to do with him."

"It's that or I take you to the Station," said Rutabaga. "You even think about leaving this place without permission, and either the Thieves will get you, and you know what they'll do to you for being an unlicensed thief, or the Assassins will, and they might take you for just a common murderer."

"I am not a murderer," the woman said. "I've never killed anyone."

"True, but given that I survived an illegal attempt last night, it would be understandable for the person who wants me dead to send another," said Rutabaga. "Throw in the fact that you're not naked already, and in my bed, they probably would like to know who you are themselves. I tend to do that to the women that try to kill me."

"So, either way I lose," the woman said.

"Yes, for the Thieves would break your arms and legs, or the Assassins would shoot you with a black crossbow bolt," said Rutabaga. "Of course, being locked up isn't much fun either."

"So, I'm stuck here?" the woman said.

"For a while," said Rutabaga. "But, I doubt it will be for much longer."

At that moment, the door opened, and in came the Head Thief. "So, this is the person who has been making a mockery of my guild." He stopped, and looked at her. "You're the maid whose been trying to become a member. Yet, there's a few things you never fill out on your forms, mainly who your parents are, along with your grandparents."

"She has a good reason, given who her maternal grandfather is," said Rutabaga. "Lord Rapiesta."

Head Thief looked at Rutabaga. "Always thought she resembled him. Do you know what he did to the last Thief that robbed him? He did things to her that make what you do to Assassins seem like a pleasant experience by comparison. And I'm not talking about what you did to the rookie, or the Slayer, which was just basic stuff, but I'm talking about when you chain them up, and do them in your wolf form, and not just in the regular manner, but when you do everything to them. All of that would have been pleasant by comparison."

"They don't complain all that much," said Rutabaga. "Most come by for another round."

"Yeah, but they tend to be capable of having children after they run into you," said Head Thief. "What that man did to my Thief, she died after the experience, and then she became a zombie, which means she can't have kids, and she and her husband always wanted some, but put it off."

Rutabaga looked at the Head Thief. "Why didn't you tell me this?"

"Well, I tried to settle it Legally, and hired an Assassin to kill him," said Head Thief. "Lets just say I got a refund. The Assassin had it just as bad as my Thief. Of course, nothing Illegal about killing an Assassin, even if they also come back as a zombie."

"Yes, he does have a lot of personal bodyguards, and none of them respect the Badge my guards wear when they come to visit," said Rutabaga. "I plan to have him legally stripped of his wealth one day."

"So, anything else about this woman that I should know?" Head Thief asked.

"Well, let's put it this way," said Rutabaga.

1131311111131113311133312221.content:
"I'm sure you've heard about the saying 'She has your eyes', Head Thief," said Rutabaga.

The Head Thief blinked. He looked at the woman. He then looked at Rutabaga. "Are you sure about that?"

Rutabaga tapped his nose. "You can trust me on that. Scents are hereditary after all."

The Head Thief looked at the woman again. "Well, I can honestly say that I know her mother." He looked back at Rutabaga. "This is going to cause an issue with my other issues."

"I suppose it would," said Rutabaga. "But, from what she has told me, all she wants is to be recognized as yours, and I'm certain that something can be worked out later."

"The Herald Dragon is not going to be happy to find out that, as the husband of a wealthy family, I have a daughter whose mother is a maid," said Head Thief.

"I don't blame you there," said Rutabaga. "He won't be happy to find out that Lord Rapiesta had an illegitimate daughter, who then had one herself. Then again, he's never happy to see, as he puts it, a mongrel. He's worse than the owner of a fine racing mare, with a fine pedigree, who just found out that the mare just had a liaison with a stallion that turns out to be a draft horse, even if that draft horse had their own impressive lineage, and thus end up having foals."

"Well, most everyone with money and wealth does consult him about whom their children should marry," said Head Thief.

"It was him who put forth the rumor about my father's supposed lineage," said Rutabaga. "A look at the eyes, nose, ears, and the chin, and 'Ah Ha! He is the Rightful Heir to the Throne! Wait? What is he doing with that bitch? Oh No! I must find a suitable mate for him!' He doesn't like me too much."

"Who does like you?" Head Thief asked. "Let's face it, you do have a lot of enemies. Some of them want you dead."

"What about you?" Rutabaga asked.

"I see you as someone to respect at any rate," said Head Thief. "We'll visit the Herald Dragon in the morning, and get the paperwork fixed up." He looked at the woman. "Mind if I escort you home, daughter? I do need to have a chat with your mother, and then I'll end up hearing it from my wife."

"Might as well, father."



Rutabaga watched them leave. Then, he set about going to bed.

11313111111311133111333122211.content:
It was before sunrise as Commander Rutabaga stood in front of the Heraldry building. Beside him was a drake, who was less than thrilled about getting up this early in the morning.

"This could have waited until later," the drake said.

"Dragon Herald, a family tree is about to be corrected, two sets of fathers reunited with their daughters, who will now be listed as heirs, setting right what was once wrong," said Commander Rutabaga. "Besides, you're always complaining about the wealthy and nobility not claiming their issues."

"Yes, the Head Thief claiming his issue as one of his own, that is something of a first," said the Dragon Herald. "Lord Rapiesta claiming his is unlikely. Truth be told, that is a line I wouldn't mind seeing die. He's done a lot of things that are highly illegal."

"Sadly, we haven't had any real proof of them, until now," said Captain Rutabaga. "Still, even the word of a former maid should count for something."

"An elderly former maid's word doesn't matter much to the likes of him, and those are the sorts that will be on the jury," said Dragon Herald. "Even if you could charge him for the rape, it has been over forty years, and her memory might not be so good."

"Still, at least he'll be forced to give compensation, to pay for the upbringing of their shared daughter," said Commander Rutabaga.

"Only because the relationship will now be a Public Record," said the Dragon Herald. "You'd be surprised at how many refuse to acknowledge their issues, many of which don't know that they are technically offspring of those with nobility in them."

Rutabaga looked at the drake. "I hope that you're not referring to my family with that comment."

The Dragon Herald glanced at him, before looking back into the fog. "Call me curious, have you yet to decide on a significant other to spend the rest of your life with, instead of these dalliances with female Assassins?"

Rutabaga chuckled as he looked back into the fog. "Do you have someone in mind? I know full well that there is no danger of the family line dying out, not with most of my siblings either being married, or at least involved with someone."

"Well, Royal bloodline aside, you are the Commander of the Guards, and a Baron, both of which count as minor nobility," said the Dragon Herald. "You also have plenty of money."

"Those aren't everything," said Rutabaga.

"That being said, I do have a list of noble families that have fallen on harder times with daughters that have yet to marry that would like to be wealthy again," the Dragon Herald said. "I also have a list of wealthy common-born families that would like a title that have eligible daughters."

"Do these respective families happen to have sons that are also of eligible age?" Rutabaga asked.

"I didn't know that your tastes ran that way," said the drake. "That being said, the answer to that is yes."

"Then match the sons of penniless nobles with the daughters of wealthy commoners, and the daughters of the penniless nobles with the sons of wealthy commoners, and they will be happier that way, or at least more satisfied," said Rutabaga. "I have no interest in getting married at all."

"I'll take your advice into consideration," said the Dragon Herald. "Still, I do know of-"

"Would you like for me to have a Contract placed on you?" Rutabaga asked. "I'm sure that the Assassins and Monster Slayers could give me a good price for someone to mount your head on their wall. I'm sure that you qualify to be placed on a List."

"Very well," said the Dragon Herald. "Ah, looks like someone is coming."
11313111111311133111333122211.title: Visiting the Dragon Herald

113131111113111331113331222113.content:
Rutabaga heard the sound of a horse galloping.

"Something must be wrong," he said. "Raynor doesn't normally move that fast without a reason."

Soon enough, a centaur emerged from the fog, and all but skidded to a stop in front of the pair, practically out of breath. Holding onto him was a uniformed woman.

"You'll twist an ankle or two doing that," said the Dragon Herald.

"What's wrong?" Rutabaga asked.

"Can't stay long," the centaur said. "I'm only here to show you what Rapiesta did to her."

Rutabaga took a look. "Seamstress?"

The woman nodded. To say that she looked like something a cat chewed up would have been an insult to whatever the cat had chewed up.

"Let me guess, he paid you to dress up as a guard, and you got more than what you'd agreed on?" Rutabaga asked.

The woman nodded.

"Get her to a Healer, and tell them to document everything," said Rutabaga.

"Planned on it," said Raynor. "Muck should be here with Rapiesta soon. Christine's looking around the place for more; she smelled a lot of blood."

"Trust a vampire to do that," said Rutabaga. "We'll see what happens when that Golem gets here."

"Thank you for inviting me to dinner Lady Mayland," Vanguard said.

Lady Ruma Mayland laughs at Vanguard's confusion. "I'm only half fairy. My father was a human bard. Say Vanguard, why don't you take a charm for yourself?"

Lady Ruma Mayland lays out three charms on her table. Each of the charms had a different design. The first charm had a powerful dragon engraved on it. The second charm had an orc engraved on it. 1213.content:
"So, what does this one do?" Vanguard asked, pointing at the one with the fat man.

Ruma looked at it. "Oops! My mistake." She placed another one next to it, which had a wolf engraved upon it. "This one might be more to your liking."

"So, just what do these charms do?" Vanguard asked.

"They give you certain attributes of the creatures they represent; skin and bones as strong as that of a dragon, the strength of an orc, the agility of a wolf, and so on," said Ruma.

"And this one?" Vangard asked, pointing at the charm with the fat man. "Lets you eat everything at those All-You-Can-Eat Buffets, right?"

"No, but when you're stuck in a situation where the only thing remotely edible is something like shoe leather, it will make your stomach strong enough to handle it," said Ruma.

"So, you don't use it to beat a Pie-Eating Contest?" Vanguard asked.

For instance, wear the dragon charm, and you could fall from the highest part of the tallest building in town, only to immediately get run over by five herds of horses, cattle, sheep, goats, and chickens, and stomped on by a flock of dragons, who decided to play with you as well, and you'd be fine, but once you took the charm off, you'd feel like you was in a fight where a dozen men all hit you with a chair. Similar situations occur in the others, where your body is utterly exhausted, and you can't really do anything, and you can only use the charm once every twenty-four hours."

Ruma laughed. "That would take a whole lot more magic than is in these charms."

I was so sick that I was bedridden for a few days. Fortunately my boss sent someone from the healers guild to take care of me.," Vanguard said.

121313.content:
"Hello Vanguard."

Vanguard stopped, and looked at the alley, and saw the figure standing in it. "Nice night, Commander."

The figure nodded, and held out an arm. "Shirt and trousers."

Vanguard took his pack off, and took out the set of clothes that every guard carried, in case Commander Rutabaga visited them, while he was traveling in his wolf form, and passed them to his Commander.

A while later, the Commander stepped out of the alley. "Saw that you visited the owner of the caravan."

"She wanted to thank me for saving her stuff," said Vanguard.

Rutabaga chuckled. "How did she thank you?"

"She gave me a charm," Vanguard said, as he pulled it out, and handed it to Rutabaga. "Gives one an iron stomach, as it were."

"Just in case someone accidentally eats Midnight Slugs again, I take," said Rutabaga, as he handed the charm back. He looked at Vanguard. "I hope you're not poking fun at my cooking?"

Vanguard grinned nervously. "Well, most humans aren't used to dwarf cooking."

"I'll keep that in mind," said Rutabaga. "That being said, I might have to correct Ruma on a few things, and remind you of a few details, namely being that the Tyrant and Head Assassin are not one and the same; I would know. Granted, the Tyrant was in position to take the Guild over, but he decided running the city would be more fun. Besides, the Head Assassin can't be Tyrant - Conflict of Interest - lots of people want the Tyrant dead, so that they can have the spot for themselves, and thus Head Assassin would have some difficulty placing a hit on himself, which is why he'll never take on the position."

"I understand," said Vanguard. "It's just that Assassins never take the cloths off of their faces, and I've never seen the Tyrant himself."

Rutabaga grinned. "Taking the cloth off of an Assassin's face means that they failed at the job, although taking their weapons off is an even worse position for them."

"You would know this very well," said Vanguard.

Rutabaga chuckled. "Got one just a little while ago - a young woman out on an Exam. She failed to hit me with aniseed oil. Funny, I've foiled her uncle before, and got the pleasure of enjoying her mother."

"Um, do you ever worry about the possibility of having, um, kids with them?" Vanguard asked.

Rutabaga grinned. "Zonkiers - best preventative that still lets you enjoy having sex, without the risk of having kids. I'm sure you've picked up a few packets here and there for your own usage."

Vanguard chuckled. "Been a little while."

"Got a box full of them at the Station," said Rutabaga. "Grab a handful and pay a visit to the Seamstress Guild - you could use some fun. Get your socks mended as well."

"I'll think about it," said Vanguard.

"Good." Rutabaga stepped back into the shadows, where Vanguard saw him take the clothes off, toss them at him, shifted into his wolf form, and padded off down the streets.

Vanguard looked at the charm, as he packed the clothes back up. He could take the Commander up on his offer of visiting the Seamstress Guild - it had been a while since he slept with a woman, and he could get a few of his clothes fixed. Then again, he could test the charm out at that place that served that REALLY spicy food, which was so hot, the place burned down at least once a week.

choices: Vanguard begins using the Glutton Charm daily to win eating challenges
