1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.content:
A growl escaped from Rutabaga's throat as he walked away from the wall.

Vanguard was about to speak, when Rutabaga looked at him. It was a look that made it clear he didn't want to talk to anyone right now. Vanguard looked at the Tyrant, who stared at the wall the vision had been on. There was no expression on the man's face. "So, what do we do now?"

"Nothing," the Tyrant said. "We do nothing."

"But, those people-"

"They will be fine," the Tyrant said. "No harm will come to them while they are in that state."

"What do you mean?" Vanguard asked.

"Research your foes before you plan your attack," said the Tyrant. "That spell is powerful, and puts those who come under it out of the fight, but they will not come to any harm otherwise. Besides, I doubt that Turnip would have done something like this without a backup plan, or even one going on alongside of this little fracas. For all you and I know, this fray might have been a distraction to conceal an even more important maneuver."

"What do you mean?" Vanguard asked.

"I saw a lot of important people getting involved in the fight, like the Head Thief, Head Monster Slayer, plus a number of better known heads of the monster clans," said the Tyrant. "But, what I didn't see were those who were the leaders' right-hand men, to say nothing about the lesser ranked and lesser-known members of the various groups. This was a distraction, to keep the demons' attention focused on one place. As for the others, I surmise that they have escaped, one way or another."

"How?" Vanguard asked.

"Magic, tunnels, cart, foot, being carried by someone stronger, and many more ways," said the Tyrant. "You never know when a mass evacuation needs to be implemented, but it pays to have a plan."

"That's over five hundred thousand people," said Vanguard. "You'd have to do a lot of coordinating."

"Never said it would have been easy," said the Tyrant. "Knowing the right people helps though."

"So, the people are safe, right?" Vanguard asked.

"Can't rule a city without people," said the Tyrant. "The city means nothing without people."

"So, what do we do?" Vanguard asked.

"That's simple," the Tyrant said.
1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.title: Distraction

1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.content:
"We contine the mission. It is vital that we meet with the dragons. By becoming an honorary Dragon it would help us penetrate the barrier that those demons could have set up," the Tyrant said.

Valahar nodded his head in agreement. "That's a good point. I may not like the dragon king that much, but I'm certain they'll see the demons as a threat as well."

"That makes sense, but I think we would need more than that to defeat those demons," Vanguard replied.

"That is true, mortal. That is why I must prepare your future king. The prophecy states that the hero of destiny and the true king will be blessed by the gods. The hero of destiny has already been blessed, but your king still needs to be blessed," Valahar said as he turned towards Wolfgang.

"I was planning on waiting before going Valaburgian size, but if it helps save my kingdom I will do anything to liberate them!"

Valahar grinned. "Excellent. Gunter, see to it that this werewolf is at my temple by sundown and bring the potions that I taught your ancestors to make."

Gunter bowed respectfully before Valahar. "As you wish Valahar the wise god of war."

Gunter escorted Wolfgang to the castle. As Wolfgang followed Gunter, Rutabaga was bliwing off some steam by getting a quick massage while in his Juggernaut form.

"That goddess was right about one this thing. This form is great for pleasure. It's about time to head out. We have to liberate Big Fat Pig City and stop that Demoness once and for all!"

Rutabaga paid the mesuse and met the others. Rutabaga and the others proceeded to the Swamp to collect another ingredient while Wolfgang gets ready to go Valaburgian size.

At this, the golem stopped, and walked back into the swamp. Rutabaga sighed as he returned back to his normal form.

"Now that is settled we can collect the mud from the swamp," Rutabaga said.

"All we need now is that gem that the dragons told us about a few days ago. That gem will take a week to find," the Tyrant said as he sighed.

Gordon placed his hand on the Tyrant's shoulder. "Don't worry about it. After we get rid of these demons you can focus on your wedding plans as you place my brother on the throne as a king who reports to your empire."

"We'll see about that. My mother did try to invade your city a few years ago and she may not approve of this marriage. Anyway we need to get going. There's a nearby orc town not too far from here," the Empress said.

The Empress tried to hide her concern, but every werewolf in the party could sense the Empress's unease.

"Except what? Jane asked.

"Except the town has some kind of magic that turns all who enter the town into orcs. Sure it helps with diplomacy, but there is a danger with such spells. Travelers who stay too long would have a hard time returning to their original race."

Toooldforthis strokes his beard. "So orcs are more adept at magic then we give them credit for. I'm pretty sure it's not that bad. The transformation reverts once we leave the town."

1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.title: Stopped, and walked back into the swamp.

1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.content:
To say that the Orcs were a violent and brutish race was something of a lie. Orcs were a peaceful and helpful race, who treated everyone equally, and loved nothing more than a good time. Problem was, an Orc's definition of "Good Time" seemed to equate to, in most other peoples' languages "A Bar Brawl". It was just how they were; receiving a punch to the face was the Orcish equivalent of "Good Morning/Day/Noon/Evening/Night" and it was exceptionally rude not to punch back.

Thus, when Rutabaga and the rest of the group transformed, Vanguard was put off-guard for a moment after some random orc decided to punch the Tyrant, and all but fell over when the Tyrant punched them back, and was even more surprised when the orc laughed, before walking away.

"What was that about?" Vanguard asked, after the orc left.

"Just being polite," the Tyrant said. "Whatever you do, don't grab your weapons."

"Why is that?" Sally asked.

"Then they'll get theirs," said Rutabaga. "Not my first time dealing with orcs. They measure status by how good one is in a fight: the better you are in a fight, the higher your rank is in their eyes. If they punch you, you punch them back, unless you want to be taken for a coward. Of course, if you can show them that you lost your hand in a fight, or were already nursing an injury, they'll punch their own selves for you. That's because once they punch you, they are honor-bound to accept a punch from you, unless you wish to insult them by not punching them."

"So, they think that you're a coward if you don't punch them, and they consider it an insult as well?" Sally asked. "I don't get it."

"You don't have to get it," said Rutabaga. "You just have to know what's expected. That being said, making friends is real easy; just outfight the toughest orc in the place, and they'll be your friend, along with everyone they've beaten. Of course, buying them a drink afterwards helps."

"That doesn't make sense," said Sally.

"It makes sense to them, and that's all that matters," said Rutabaga. "Just don't grab your weapons. A fistfight is one thing, but weapons is much more serious."

"Why is that?" Vanguard asked.

"Because either you or the other orc is going to die," said the Tyrant. "And since most orcs know how to fight like an orc, they'll have the edge in a fight."
1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.title: Entering the Orc Town

Rutabaga and the others proceed to a grand fortress. The Fortess itself was a marvel to behold. Being in the center of town various orcs were having a blast as a few bards began playing a catchy tune. When they walked up to the gate they were halted by two guards.

"Halt! What is your reason for visiting Cheif Maximus?" The orc guard asked. The orc sniffed the air before he returned to interrogating Rutabaga and his group. "You're travellers from out of town judging by your scent. Now tell us why you're here."

The Tyrant stepped forward and preceded to speak. "I am the Tyrant of Big Fat Pig City. Your cheiftain and I met two years ago at a gala that I held. I am on a quest to find a gem for the dragons. It is imperative that I find this gem so I can crush those cowardly demons who took over my city while I was away!"

The Tyrant was fuming with anger. Fortunately he wasn't foolish enough to draw his sword.

"Our Cheiftain has heard of these demons. However before we permit you to see Chief Maximus the strongest of you must pass a test."

"What kind of test?" Rutabaga asked.

What's Wolfgang up to in Valaburg?

"Before you can meet with our chief you must first overcome the Gaunlet! The Gaunlet is a challenge where challengers try to tame a Trimagar in the fastest time possible," the guard said.

Classic Maximus. Posing as a guard in order to test the strength of one's character. I'm pretty sure the werewolves have already caught onto the ploy, but this should be fun to watch. The Tyrant thought as he turned his gaze towards Rutabaga.

Vanguard scratched his head in confusion. He had no idea what was going on. "What's a Trimagar?"

"A Trimagar is a three-headed dragonoid creature. Though not a dragon they have a similar build to most dragon except that they have the head of an alligator, horns of a bull, and have the ability to creating webbing like a spider," Mauvius said.

Sally gulped and looked towards Rutabaga and Gordon. "That sounds intense."

"It is. I was going to have that large werewolf take the Gauntlet, but I feel like his twin brother is more powerful then he let's on. In fact I think that they may be equally matched," Maximus said.

"So you want us both to take on the Gauntlet?" Gordon asked.

Rutabaga goes into his Juggernaut form seeing that it would be rude not to show off his true power before the chieftain.

"Seems like this form adjusts to my current species. A trivial observation, but this is necessary for the mission. Are you ready Gordon?"

Vanguard punched Maximus back in order not to offend him. Maximus then led Rutabaga and the others to the arena.

Meanwhile in Valaburg, Wolfgang was standing inside Valahar's temple. As instructed he was completely naked so he wouldn't ruin his clothes. The inside of the temple was decorated with statues of gold and silver. The statues were of Valaburgian war heroes ranging from Kings to solitary merceenaries. Each statue had a different weapon in its hand. Other than the statues there was a massive table filled with food and several weights on the other side.

"This is impressive. Who knew that a god of War could have an eye for decorating. Yet again this is a massive room."

Wolfgang then noticed Valahar enter the room. The war god looked slightly larger than a few hours ago and he was wearing a silver tunic and a pair of of black trousers.

"You're on time. Let me explain how this will work. You will spend one month in this temple. All of my temples amplify the effects of the growth tonic. Rarely do I consider inviting mortals to stay in my temple, but my match with your brother's duplicate proved that your family comes from good stock," Valahar said.

"That's the reason why you decided to bestow your blessing upon me?" Wolfgang asked.

"Yes and no. I see potential in you, but whether you keep my blessing depends if you can prove your strength to me like your brother. If you can match me in a sparring contest you'll become the biggest and strongest werewolf around. If you lose you'll revert back to your current size."

Wolfgang scratched his chin and grinned. "I figured there would be some sort of catch. This should be interesting" Wolfgang said.

"Let's get started. Your trial begins now!" Valahar said as he offered Wolfgang a goblet full of growth tonic.
1213132333132333332331231233231222333312.title: What's Wolfgang up to in Valaburg?

Meanwhile in a different dimension, the gods were watching the heroes via a crystal ball.

"So the future king of Big Fat Pig City thinks he can pass Valahar's challenge. Very few mortals are successful," a tall goddess dressed in a pink silk dress said.

The goddess's name is Delania the queen of the gods. Beside her was a buff god wearing a blood red tunic named Pyronio.

"That may be true Delania, but after witnessing his older brother's double face off against Valahar I can see the future king of Big Fat Pig City succeeding," Pyronio said. 1213132333133.content:
It was a while later, when the group found themselves in a forest.

"Company, Halt," Rutabaga called out. He looked around. "This isn't the right place. Stay here, and don't move." He got off his horse, and walked into the forest.

Vanguard looked at the Tyrant. The man's face was impassive, but there was something that said he didn't miss anything. He looked at Toooldforthis. "Do you know what's going on?"

The Mage looked at him. "I have an idea, but I don't want to say it. Stay by your younger guard. If we are where I think we are, she'll need someone she knows by her at all times."

"What's going on?" Vanguard asked.

"We're not where we should be, that's what," the Tyrant said.

"That's for sure," said Snatchem. "These trees are not the sort that grow in the Wishing Forest."

"How would you know that?" Vanguard asked.

"You have to know what wood is valuable to those in the market for the rare stuff," said Snatchem.

"Yes, and don't breath any of the flowers in," said Tetra. "I recognize some of them, and they are highly dangerous."

"So, what do we do?" Sally asked.

"We wait until the Commander returns," the Tyrant said. "He'll let us know."

"And I'm back."

The group looked behind them, and saw the Commander, as he walked up to the group, and got on his horse. "It's just as I feared. We're in their forest alright."

"What forest is that?" Sally asked.

"Let's put it this way, I'd rather be in the Enchanted Forest, or the Forbidden Forest, or even Death Forest, than in this place," said Rutabaga. "This place is nowhere near as friendly as those places."

"So, where are we?" Vanguard asked.

"Fairy Tale Forest, and we're stuck here until they decide to toss us out," said Rutabaga.

"That is annoying," the Tyrant said.

"What's so bad about this place?" Sally asked.

"Because you're stuck in one of their stupid stories, whether you like it or not," said Rutabaga. "And they try to force you into the role they want you to do, whether you want to do it or not."

"So, what do we do?" Vanguard asked.

"If you feel you are doing something you don't want to do, do the opposite," said Rutabaga. "If you're forced into being a polite gentleman, be a rude lout, and visa versa. Do whatever it takes to show them that they are not in control of you."

"Why?" Sally asked.

"Otherwise you will have no free will," said the Tyrant. "You will be their puppet, and plaything."

"But, what's the worse that could happen?" Sally asked.

"A few years ago, they caused the deaths of ten good wolves, some of whom I knew from when I ran with the packs, to say nothing about the deaths of twenty old ladies, ten who were eaten by the ten wolves who were killed by woodsmen, and ten others who were burned in their own ovens, after they tried to eat some children, who shoved them into said ovens," said Rutabaga.

"Sounds like a story, or two, I heard as a child," said Sally. "Fiction, right? I mean, wolves don't go after humans, normally."

"They don't, for most know better," said Rutabaga. "However, they do in Fairy Tales, and this forest is filled with those."

"And we are stuck in this forest, unless we don't act like we're part of the story," said the Tyrant. "It will force them to either reveal themselves, or kick us out."

"So, who rules here?" Sally asked.

"Fairies," said Rutabaga. "Only they aren't the ones I'd want to be Godmothers for my children."

"So, why don't we go back the way we came?" Vanguard asked.

"Already tried that," said Rutabaga. "You'll just end up back here again. Tried it three times from three different directions. The only way to go someplace else, is to not try to leave."

"That doesn't make sense," said Sally.

"It does around here," said Rutabaga. "The fairies don't like it when people try to leave, and they certainly don't like me."

"Why is that?" Sally asked.

"It's complicated, but here's something that will do for the moment...."
1213132333133.title: They take a wrong turn somewhere.

12131323331331.content:
"I killed a few of the bastards the last time we met," said Rutabaga.

"How?" Vanguard asked.

"By having just one thought about each of them as I drove my sword through them, and tore their throats out with my teeth," said Rutabaga. "And that thought wasn't 'Die!', just to let you know."

"What was it?" Vanguard asked.

"Let's just say that, among the wolves who were killed, was a bitch that I, shall we say, knew very well from when I ran with her pack," said Rutabaga.

"Was she someone you loved?" Sally asked.

"Well, the thought about being her mate, and staying in wolf form, had crossed my mind," said Rutabaga. "Ultimately, I decided against it, became a Guard like my parents, and she found herself a mate, but we kept in touch, and I'd visit her at times, play with her pups, and that sort of stuff, but every now and then, we'd reflect, talk about what could have been, but I had my Duty, and I'd go back to the City. To be honest, I did love her, and I think she loved me. What those fairies did to her was despicable - they had her kill an old woman, and then had a woodsman kill her in turn. All I did was think about her as I killed those fairies."

"What was her name?" Sally asked.

Rutabaga smiled. "It's a little complicated to say in the human tongue, as there's a few things involved in speaking wolf, but 'She-Who-Smells-of-the-Flowers-from-the-Southern-part-of-the-Lower-Valley 9; would come fairly close."

"That's a mouthful," said Vanguard.

"It's much quicker in Canine," said Rutabaga. "Still, she was on my mind."
12131323331331.title: I killed a few of them the last time we met.

Vanguard is ambused by a rouge witch and wizard
121313233313313.content:
After Rutabaga had finished speaking a strange blue light began to make its way towards Vanguard and the others.

"Looks like the story is about to start. Whatever you do, do the exact opposite of what they want!" Rutabaga yelled.

"Foolish wolf. We modified our spell so you and your friends will have no choice to live out the story. You should be losing all freewill right about now," a mischievous voice said.

Soon enough Vanguard and the others were blinded by the blue light. When Vanguard opened his eyes he was in a tavern filled with people of all races. Before Vanguard could question anything a woman in a red dress approached him.

"Excuse me Lord Green, but the Great Wolf King sent his messenger to give this to you," the woman said as she handed him a letter.

Mentally Vanguard tried to refuse the letter, but he was surprised to discover that he had no control of his. He tried to speak what was on his mind, but he wound up saying "Thanks darling. I'll be sure to read it."

Vanguard was shocked that he was powerless to do anything. No matter how much he willed himself to do the opposite his body and mouth were acting on autopilot.

"It says here that the King Blackfur is holding a feast. Usually he's busy trying to kill the Warlord for his treason against the kingdom," Vanguard said against his will.

So Rutabaga is the king in this story. If I can control my body or mouth then I believe my comrades are suffering the same fate. I have to fight this spell.

As Vanguard tried to fight the spell his body was exiting the tavern. Tried as he might the spell was too strong, but Vanguard won't give up too easily.
121313233313313.title: Beginning of a Twisted Fairy Tale

You'll have to do it during the party, in front of everyone, to shock them too.
You'll have to do it after the Abduction.
1213132333133131.content:
Reluctantly, Vanguard found himself at a grand castle. However, the moment he passed through the doorway, he was shocked by what he saw. He'd all but had been expecting the knights and guards to be wearing white shining armor, but instead they were wearing black, and malevolent looking armor. Surprisingly enough, he found himself in control of himself.

"What's going on?" he asked. "Am I in the right place?"

At this point, an evil-looking wizard appeared in front of Vanguard. "You are, Vanguard."

Vanguard looked at him. "Toooldforthis?"

The wizard nodded. "The Commander figured out how to bypass the spell, all but instantly. Seems that Fairy Tale Spells don't work on those who are in a partial shift between two different forms in - you can't have a Noble King and a Savage Wolf in the same place at the same time, you understand, and he's stuck in this halfway state of man and wolf, and it's not like he's in a normal werewolf form where he's a mixture, but is stuck trying to become one or the other. The shock of seeing him like that is enough to shake off certain aspects of the spell for others."

"But, why are you dressed like that?" Vanguard asked.

"Because I'm supposed to be his Good Magician," said Toooldforthis. "Instead, I'm his Evil Wizard. You must twist your role in order to have any control."

"Where are the others?" Vanguard asked.

"Let's put it this way, the Tyrant is in the role of the Warlord, but it seems he's been in this sort of thing before, and has changed himself into a Noble Rebel Bandit Chieftain type-of role," said Toooldforthis. "Terta and Snatchem are his second-in-commands, but the Tyrant has worked to make them, and the rest, noble outlaws. As for Sally, she's stuck playing the role of the Royal Princess, and the Tyrant is supposed to abduct her and that sort of stuff."

"What about me?" Vanguard asked.

"You're supposed to be the hero, who is to rescue the Princess from the Warlord, and marry her," said Toooldforthis. "Obviously, we can't let that come to pass."

"So, what am I supposed to do?" Vanguard asked.

"Be an evil asshole for one," said Toooldforthis, "We haven't been able to shock Sally out of the spell yet."

"So, like I asked, what do I do?"

Toooldforthis looked at him. "You're going to have to rape her."

Vanguard looked at him in shock. "You can't be serious. I can't do that!"

"It isn't a matter of choice," said Toooldforthis. "She's supposed to fall in love with you, and we can't have that! Besides, the Tyrant's role is that he's supposed to try doing that to her anyways, before you rescue her from him."

"But, she's just a kid, practically."

"Do you want to be trapped in this place or not?" Toooldforthis asked.

"No."

"Then you will either rape her, or be abusive towards her at any rate," said Toooldforthis. "You must twist your role, and be the Villain, while the Tyrant becomes the Hero."

"So, in order for her to be free, I have to do it?" Vanguard asked.

"You need to be abusive at any rate," said Toooldforthis. "You need to place her in a state of shock to free her from the spell. She's the Key Character to the story; shock her, and the spell will be broken for everyone, not just us."

"I don't like the idea," said Vanguard. "I mean, she only joined the Guards this week, and we barely know each other."

"Apologize after we're free," said Toooldforthis. "Otherwise we're stuck here for the rest of our lives."

"So, do I have to do this now?" Vanguard asked.

Toooldforthis sighed. "Well, about that detail...."
1213132333133131.title: Shocking Information

choices: The Tyrant and his band come to save Vanguard
Vanguard is teleported somewhere by an undercover sorceress
12131323331331312.content:
"You'll have to do it during the party, in front of everyone, to shock them too."

Vanguard gulped. He didn't like the sound of the idea and felt like if Toooldforthis was telling the truth that he and the others will still be playing into the fairies's hands.

Hours later, Vanguard was at the party. There were lords and ladies dressed in black, purple, or red. Rutabaga was nowhere to be seen, but Sally was talking to a few noblemen.

As Vanguard approached Sally, Sally herself began walking towards Vanguard.

"The great hero Vanguard. What brings a lousy hero like you here. You know my guardian is the great and cruel wolf king did you not?" Sally said with disdain.

Vanguard had a feeling that something wasn't right, but he decided to attempt to grope Sally's breasts anyway. However, Sally kick Vanguard in the groin before he had the chance.

"The fairies were right. A spy sent from the Warlord or should I say Heroic Warrior would dare to assault me. Guards! Throw this spy into the dungeon!"

Vanguard then drew his sword. He knew that he was playing into the fairies hands. It would of been too convienent for Rutabaga and Toooldforthis to break free of the spell. The fairies probably anticipated this and went along with it anyway.

As guards and nobles drew their swords Vanguard saw Rutabaga standing in a balcony. Rutabaga grinned evilly as his guards came upon Vanguard. Vanguard tried to fight his way among the noblemen and noblewomen who were all trying to kill him.

All seemed hopeless until...
12131323331331312.title: A plan that was always meant to backfire

choices: The table was knocked over, and the two were tossed against the wall
Kissed her, but the spell wasn't quite broken just yet. Something was missing
121313233313313121.content:
"Fight for your Freedom!"

Vanguard looked, and saw the Tyrant come into the party with a band of what looked like Outlaws. He then saw that some of the others seemed shock at the sight of the Tyrant. For one thing, he wasn't dressed like a Hero should. He looked like the Ultimate Evil that some claimed him to be, as he booted and punched, and shoved at the guards and nobles.

The Tyrant soon stood before Vanguard. "Are you alright?"

"I am," said Vanguard. "What's going on?"

"Did you think it was going to be easy to assault a Royal Princess?" the Tyrant asked.

"I thought the plan was too easy," said Vanguard.

The Tyrant grinned. "I know. Me and the Commander set that up on purpose, so that the Fairies knew what we were going to do."

"So, what's the real plan?" Vanguard asked.

"You have to kiss Sally," the Tyrant said.

Vanguard looked over at Sally, who was busy fighting the Outlaws. "That might prove to be tricky."

"You don't know this story, do you?" the Tyrant said with a grin. "She isn't the Real Princess." He pointed over at an old servant woman, who was cowering under a banquet table. "She is."

"Wait, how do you know this?" Vanguard asked.

"I'm naturally immune to these magics," the Tyrant said. "I see the Truth Behind the Story. Kiss Sally, and the story will break."

"Then who's-"

"Never mind that!" the Tyrant shouted, shoving Vanguard towards the table, knocking him down. "Kiss the old woman!" He then turned towards the Fake Sally, and charged, drawing an evil-looking sword.

Vanguard looked at the old woman. There was fear in her eyes. "Sally? Is that you?"

The woman looked at him. "Help me," she mouthed.

Vanguard leaned forward and .....
121313233313313121.title: The Real Plan

choices: Vanguard and Sally Kiss, breaking the spell
The Other Fairies come and attack.
1213132333133131212.content:
"Oh no you don't!"

The table flew away, and Vanguard and the old woman were exposed before the fake Sally, who had a highly evil look on her face.

"You think that you can kiss her and break the story!" the impostor yelled. "I think not!"

At this, the pair were magically flung against the wall.

The impostor walked up to them, just as Rutabaga landed next to her. "The story will never end. Kill them."

"With pleasure, Mistress," said Rutabaga, as he drew his sword.

"Commander," Vanguard said. "Don't do this."

"He can't help it," the impostor said. "He's fully human, meaning he's under my control." She looked at Rutabaga. "Make their deaths painful."

"As you wish." In that moment, Rutabaga's head changed from that of a human, into that of a wolf. Also, in that moment, he shoved the sword into the impostor, and charged them into the wall, the sword going through the stone, pinning the impostor like a butterfly.

The impostor turned her head. "Impossible."

The look on Rutabaga's wolf head was one of pure anger as he lunged forward, his jaws enveloping her neck, as he tore her head off from her shoulders. Blood dripped from his teeth as the head fell, and he started spitting.

"How?" Vanguard asked.

Rutabaga grinned, and pulled up his pant leg. The leg underneath was that of a wolf's.

"You weren't full human," said Vanguard.

Rutabaga's head shifted into that of a human. "You have no idea how difficult, nor how painful, it is to be in a partial shift like this, especially for extended periods of time."

"Is it over?" the Real Sally asked.

Rutabaga grinned. "Well, Vanguard still has to kiss you, but that shouldn't be too much of a problem now."

"It shouldn't be," the Tyrant said. "Not if they move quickly."

125.content:
Sarge Ryliner is one of the few guards that has worked with Rutabaga over the years. He's the third highest ranking officer of the guard being outranked only by Wolfgang and Rutabaga.

Unlike other guards that serve under Rutabaga he is also trying to form a guild. For ages he's been striving to create a guild that would dedicate itself to the betterment of Big Fat Pig City. The type of guild he wants to create is...
125.title: Sarge Ryliner

choices: Suddenly a scream is heard, and another, and the Ringing of a Bell - Trouble!
1251.content:
Ryliner looked at his plan. It was a good plan. A standing military branch to defend Big Fat Pig City from invaders. It was good. That was when the door to his office opened, and Rutabaga came in.

Ryliner stood up. "Hello, sir."

"Sit down," said Rutabaga. "You know I don't like being called 'Sir'." He then looked at Ryliner's plan. "You actually want to form an army."

"Well, you know, to protect the city," said Ryliner, as he sat back down. "I mean, given our history, we wouldn't want someone to take the place over."

Rutabaga chuckled. "We've been invaded hundreds of times, and every time they occur, we get a new ethnic community, like the Mongs, and they have some good cooking by the way."

"Just a bunch of barbarians, really," said Ryliner. "Riding on horses in circles, shooting their arrows, all while the walls protected the inhabitants."

"Then someone stole their horses, and eventually their tents turned into houses, they had families, and eventually, their community got walled in with the rest of the city," said Rutabaga. "Also, isn't your grandmother on your father's side a Mong? She wanted to join the Guard not too long ago, and given that she destroyed a dozen training dummies, I took her on as a cook to make up for the damage she did."

Ryliner blushed nervously. "She keeps on talking to me in that heathen dialect when I get something to eat. I mean, the people who live here should speak in our language."

"My grandparents on my father's side talk to me in Dwarfish, but you don't hear me complaining about it," said Rutabaga. "My mother even picked up on how to swear in it!"

"Nothing against dwarves, some of our best guards are dwarves, and I'm proud to have them on the force," Ryliner said, for the benefit of the dwarves listening listening outside. "Same with Mongs! I'm proud to be a quarter-Mong!"

Rutabaga grinned. "You still want to create a military guild though, right?"

Ryliner chuckled nervously. "Wouldn't mind forming one."

"Might have it's uses," said Rutabaga. "See the Tyrant about it."

"Thank you, sir," said Ryliner.
1251.title: A Military Guild

choices: A powerful reality altering spell hits Big Fat Pig City
12512.content:
Suddenly a scream is heard, and another, and the Ringing of a Bell - Trouble! Sarge Ryliner and Rutabaga rush to the scene. Once there they see a crowd of clergymen and clergywomen gathering around an unconcious woman.

The unconscious woman was none other than the guildmistress of the Seamstresses Guild. Rutabaga sniffed the air and found something was amiss.

"What happened here?" Rutabaga asked.

Ryliner looked at the guildmistress and noticed broken mirror shards scattered on the ground.

"Nothing to be concerned about. We were just performing an exorcism," a clergyman said.

"Why does she still smell like she's possessed?" Rutabaga asked.

"We aren't done yet, but she does need medical attention. Could you find a healer. We could really use one," a clergywoman replied.

"We'll find a healer for you. Be sure to have the Seamtress guildmistress fully exorcised. The last thing we need is a demonic invasion," Ryliner said.

"We will," the clergyman said as Rutabaga and Ryliner walked off to find a healer.

As Rutabaga and Sarge Ryliner were walking they couldn't shake the feeling that something was amiss.

"Sir, do you ever get the feeling that those clergymen could be up to something? There's been a lot of strange things happening as of late. Some people are saying that a new mysterious cult has appeared.

Rutabaga scratches his chin. "Yeah, I've been looking into them. I have Carol Swaynarain looking into them. This could be an omen. If this omen leads to the townspeople wanting to crown me king then no thank you."

Sarge chuckled. "I have a feeling that the gods wouldn't want you as king anyway. Maybe as a hero, but a king? They would find someone better suited anyway."

"You're right. They would choose Wolfgang anyway. He would be more suited anyway. The Tyrant would even appoint him as a puppet king if he felt like it. Yet hopefully nothing terrible happens."
12512.title: Troubling omens

choices: Suddenly a scream is heard, and another, and the Ringing of a Bell - Trouble!
125123.content:
"What do you think would happen if a group of demons did take over the place?" Ryliner asked.

Rutabaga chuckled. "Same thing that happens to everyone else; they'd get robbed, stabbed in the back, forced to sell the deeds to their homes for a night's rest, and end up buying shirts that say 'I saw the Big Fat Pig, and all I got was this lousy Shirt!' Then, we'd end up getting a community of genuine hell-raisers, who'd bitch and moan about the place being a pit full of scum, only for them to deck anyone from outside the city who dares say anything bad about it."

Ryliner chuckled. "Sounds about right. I mean, even the non-humans who live here aren't half-bad, once you get to know them." He then remembered who he was talking to. "Not that I'm saying anything about you personally, Sir."

"I'll keep that in mind when the Tyrant asks me if I think you'd be a good military leader for that guild you want to form," said Rutabaga. "Of course, I hope that you remember to keep an open employment policy, like the Guard does; sometimes you find out that a few dozen gnomes in the right places can make ambushing the enemy easier, and they only require the same pay as a single human. Likewise, having a single dragon flaming a hundred men at once can be worth paying them the price of fifty men."

"Um, right," said Ryliner. "I've heard that the Monster Slayers are opening their ranks to Monsters, and the like."

"Like the saying goes," said Rutabaga. "Set a Thief to catch a thief."

"I don't know if the Assassins would do that," said Ryliner.

"Assassins stick to humans," said Rutabaga. "For the most part."

"You'd think they'd learn a thing or two from their attempts to kill you," said Ryliner.

"Keeps me from being bored at night," said Rutabaga. "That, and it saves me from paying for a Seamstress when they send a woman after me. Also, it lets me know that I'm pissing the right people off."

"You might also be pissing the wrong people off too," said Ryliner.

"So long as no one goes after my guards," said Rutabaga.

"I think they got the message after the last time," said Ryliner. "You turned that guy into nothing but a body, and a head with only a pair of ears attached to it. Then there was that Lord who tried to place a contract on one after he caught them in bed with his daughter - you placed a Double Contract on him, unless he removed the Contract from the guard."

"No one messes with my guards," said Rutabaga. "Rob them, steal their armor, money, and weapons, break their arms and legs, but no one rapes or murders them, unless they want to pay the price."

"Right," said Ryliner.
125123.title: Other

choices: Jessica challenges them to a game of darts
Jessica issues a game of fate or liberation
1251233.content:
Just as they were about to find a healer a beautiful woman dressed in a green and gold dress approached them.

"Hello boys. Would you luck to play a game at my club?"

The womam was known as Jessica Fortunata, an infamous compulsive gambler who's known to bet every once of gold she owns in any type of game. The fact is she became exceedingly wealthy due to her gambling. There are also rumors that all who owe her debt have no choice but to work for her until they paid her back every gold coin they owed.

Sarge and Rutabaga didn't take too kindly to gambling. A good number of guards often get caught in a gambling trap and have even sold their souls in extreme cases. Also, they considered Jessica to be the most crooked among Big Fat Pig City's wealthy.

"Not today," Sarge Ryliner said.

Jessica furrowed her brows and puckered her lips. She then applied lip balm to her lips. "Oh come on! Don't you want to meet my new waiter? He's a darling young dragon who gambled away all of his first paycheck from the guard."

Rutabaga let out a low growl. "What! I recruited Tarvonarch two weeks ago! We'll play your game as long as you let my guard go."

"Sir! You can't be serious? Fortunata is known to occaissionally cheat. She'll just wind up cheating and the whole guard would become her servants," Ryliner said.

"As interesting as that sounds I'm only interested in playing with you. So what are you waiting for. Let's risk everything like no tomorrow!"
1251233.title: Kessica Fortunata the compulsive gambler

choices: Jessica is a formidable card player, and wins.
After a tough game, Rutabaga wins, but Jessica plays Fair and Square
After a hard game, Rutabaga manages to finally catch Jessica Cheating
Something interrupts the card game Rutabaga and Jessica are playing.
12512333.content:
Rutabaga looked at Jessica, and then, much to Ryliner's surprise, the commander started to laugh.

"I'll tell you what; keep Tarvonarch," said the werewolf. "If that dragon is so foolish to waste his pay on gambling, I don't want him as a Guard. In fact, that goes for the rest of them that waste it all." He started to walk away.

Ryliner caught up to him. "You're just going to leave Tarvonarch with her?"

"Might as well," Rutabaga said, loudly. "Dumb fool needs to learn his lesson, and pay off his debt."

That was when Ryliner saw Rutabaga's fingers. They went one.... two..... three...

"Alright," Jessica said, having run up to them. "What will it take for you to play a game with me, Commander?"

Rutabaga grinned, as he turned towards her. "Cash stakes only. Whatever money we currently have in our pockets; no more, no less. Play fair, and my guards have to honor the debts. Cheat, and you'll be having issues with the Thieves Guild, to say nothing about the fact that my guards will owe you no money."

"Funny you should mention the Thieves Guild," said Jessica.

"Don't tell me; the Head Thief owes you money."

Jessica laughed. "No, but I am a member of the Guild, and all of my dues are up to date."

"I see," said Rutabaga. "Explains a few things."

"What things?" Ryliner asked.

"She's allowed to cheat, and not get her fingers broken," said Rutabaga. "In that case, if I catch you cheating, you forfeit whatever debts my men owe. If I can't catch you cheating, then they have to pay their debts."

Jessica grinned. "I'm glad you understand."

"You'd better be good," said Rutabaga. "My eyes are good at catching card tricks, my ears hear the sounds of mechanical contraptions, and my nose smells magic."

Jessica chuckled. "I only use such things on unlicensed cheaters. I prefer using my head, and my ability to read people."

Rutabaga grinned. "I see. Well, I'll probably be rather difficult then."

"We shall see," said Jessica. "Come to my place, and we'll play a game of cards."
12512333.title: Setting the Bait

125123334.content:
Jessica guides Rutabaga and Sarge Ryliner to the Golden Shamrock, the biggest club in all of Big Fat Pig City. The club was run by those who either owe debt to Jessica or work there on their own volition. However, only members of the Thieves guild are allowed to run and host the games. As such Jessica can continue her questionable ventures and make a profit.

Once inside Rutabaga and Jessica started playing right away. Ryliner watched as each played ended in a draw. Of course Rutabaga and Jessica bluffed from time to time, but that was allowed since it's a legal move in any card game.

All was going well until the performers stopped singing and a sudden silence filled the room. Then shouts began to erupt from across the club. All eyes turned toward the Fate or Liberation table.

"Hey, punk! What kind of trick are you trying to pull!" The muscular host shouted as he pulled a classy elf by the collar.

"You call me a punk? You've been cheating the whole time. So what's wrong with stealing from a thief?" The elf asked.

Jessica and Rutabaga stop their game as the situation spirals into chaos . They walk over towards the unfolding chaos.

"What seems to be the issue here?" Jessica asked.

"I caught this elf cheating. He was using rigged dice."

Jessica puts two fingers on her chin. "Do you have a thieving license? If you do I can let this slide. If not I'll have to inform the Head Thief."

The elf scoffs and begins cackling. "A license to cheat? That's rich. It's just a game to make money."

In a blink on an eye the Head Thief appears. Head Thief Hooler was infamous for his ability to infiltrate places without being noticed. Given that he's an anthropomorphic owl he has an advantage over most species.

"Show your license to the leprechaun. If you don't have one then Bartholomew has the right to break your fingers," Hooler said referring to the host of Fate or Liberation.

The elf began laughing even harder until Bartholomew pickpocketed him and grab both his hands. "You don't have a license, bub."

The elf screams in pain as Bartholomew crushes his fingers with his bare hands. Sarge gasps at the brutality and display of strength. He's seen various methods for breaking people's fingers, but rarely has he seen someone use their bare hands to do it.

A few moments later the elf was stripped down to his skivies. Everyone looked on as the elf tried to run only to be apprehended by Sarge Ryliner.

"Where do you think you're going? You're going to jail," Sarge said.

Jessica sighed. "I guess our game will have to resume another day. Oh and don't worry about your dragon guard. The Tyrant already paid the debt earlier."

Rutabaga looked at the Leprechaun and rolled his eyes. "Let me guess, this happened during our game."

"That's right. But now you owe the Tyrant a favor. I believe he wants to speak to Sarge Ryliner. I'm pretty sure it's due to a need for a new guild or something. Until next time."
125123334.title: A cheater found in the Golden Shamrock

choices: You can create a Limited Defense Guild
You can set up a Historical Reenactment Guild, with Weapons
1251233341.content:
"Ah, Commander, so good to see you."

Ryliner stood still, not wanting to move. He also had a certain feeling where he hoped that he wouldn't need to change his trousers. "Sir, he's right behind us, isn't he?"

Rutabaga turned his head. "He is."

"Walk with me."

The two guards followed behind the Tyrant.

"Sargent Ryliner, I hear that you wish to open a Military Guild, or some sort of Armed forces," the Tyrant said. "Is this true?"

"Well, sir, I was thinking about the safety of the city," said Ryliner.

"So am I," the Tyrant said. "Our walls have always protected us, and it is fairly easy to call for the Militia, which is any armed citizen who wishes to defend the city, which tends to be most of them, especially those who are not humans. There's a lot of people out there who wish to see non-humans dead, or worse. Here, however, they are free to live their lives in relative peace and harmony." He stopped, picked up a snack from a dwarf vendor, and tried it. "Excellent rat. Got any ketchup?" The vendor put some on. The Tyrant took another bite. "Very good. I might have to ask you over the next time the Mountain Clans wish to talk to me."

"Thank you, your Lordship," the vendor said.

"One for the Commander," the Tyrant said. "He enjoys a good rat on occasion."

"That he does," the vendor said. The vendor looked at the Commander. "Saw your father the other day. He's looking well."

"That he is," said Rutabaga, as he accepted the rat. He tried it. "Very good. Ketchup please?"

"Right you are." The vendor looked at Ryliner. "One for you?"

"Well, um..." Ryliner saw the Tyrant watching him. "A small one, if possible, with ketchup?"

"Here you are."

"Thank you," the Tyrant said, as he paid for the rats. "As you can see, thanks to their creativity, we have less of a rodent problem."

"Noticed," Ryliner said, as he eyed the rat. "Doesn't look very tasty though."

"Tastes better with the ketchup," said Rutabaga.

"It's better than some of the stuff you normally eat around here, and that's saying something," the Tyrant said.

Ryliner gulped, and took a bite. "It's going to take some getting used to."

"Then there's the different nationalities and religions," the Tyrant said. "Out beyond those walls, they clash with one another, fighting over everything, killing each other. Here, they live in relative harmony. The Kincs with the Shinz, the dwarves with trolls, and even the lion with the sheep, after the sheep has made sure that the lion has already eaten of course."

"Is there a point to this?" Ryliner asked.

"They come here because we are a peace-loving city, which has no standing military that can be used for aggressive purposes," the Tyrant said. "Some say that a military is needed for defense, but I see no need for one, as it might tempt my future successors to engage in aggressive maneuvers to take other peoples' lands, as opposed to the accepted practice of lying, deceiving, and other non-violent methods."

"I understand, sir," said Ryliner.

"That being said," the Tyrant said. "My decision is this....
1251233341.title: Sarge Ryliner meets the Tyrant

choices: Alexio pulls him aside and threatens to make his life a living hell
12512333412.content:
"You can create a Limited Defense Guild. Big Fat Pig City does need extra protection and the city guards have limited resources."

Sarge sighed. In a way he was getting what he wanted, but he figured that the Tyrant could change his mind later if a new guild or club rises to prominence.

"I agree to your terms sir," Ryliner replied.

"I'm glad we agree. Before you can start a guild you must meet a few requirements. You must have a minimum of four people in your guild. All costs to starting a new guild is 500 gold coins. Last, but not least you have to find a patron. The patron may be a member of your guild or someone outside your guild."

Ryliner nodded in agreement. The funding wouldn't be a problem. He can also easily gather four people too. The toughest thing was finding a patron. Sure some guilds are lucky since their patrons are members of their guilds or extremely wealthy. Ryliner has even heard scenarios where gods or goddesses would become patrons for a guild. Yet again Big Fat Pig City is considered as neutral territory for all the gods of Bowlworld.

"You have 30 days to meet these conditions. See you later."

The Tyrant then proceeded to play a game of cards with the head thief.

"There you have it. I believe someone should of found a healer for the guildmistress of the Seamtress guild," Rutabaga said. "Good luck with the new guild."

Rutabaga then walked out of the Golden Shamrock. As soon as Rutabaga left Bartholomew approached Ryliner.

"So you plan on starting a new guild. Count me in."

Ryliner was surprised. He didn't expect someone working for Jessica Fortunata to be quick to join the guild.

"Great, so what can you do besides thieving that would benefit the Limited Defense Guild?"

"For starters I'm a demigod. I've done countless jobs over the years. Also, I'm a licensed Assassin. I can legally snuff out any threats," Bartholomew said.

"I see. So you're a jack of all trades. That will be very useful. Yet why haven't you taken jobs to go after the Commander? It's just that you don't come off as an Assassin."

Bartholomew laughed. "Assassinating werewolves isn't my thing. Also killing freeloaders is beneath me. Yet he does have some regallity about him though. Yet his brother is the one who's most likely going to become king if fables are to believed."

"Yeah, Rutabaga's hobbies do give that impression. Yet we need to find two more members and a patron though."

"So you boys need a member for your guild, eh. I got nothing better to do and I'm interested in learning a trade anyway."

Ryliner turns around and sees a faerie dressed as a huntswoman. "Who are you?"

The faerie smirks and curtsies before Sarge Ryliner. "I am Deliana Cressflune. I grew up foraging for my folks and hunting all sorts of critters. Yet what's a nature faerie to do when she can only use her magic to survive?"

"That might come in handy. The more talent the better the Limited Defense Guild can be," Ryliner said.

As Ryliner continued speaking with his new guild members an anthropomorphic tiger approached them. The tiger was immensely fat and wore a silver and black outfit.

"Starting a guild. You need a patron, right. I can find you a patron for a fee," the tiger said as he gave Ryliner a pamphlet.

Ryliner looked at the tiger in frustration. "You're Alexio Crassroar. You swindle new guilds out of their money so you could stuff your face. Thanks, but no thanks."

That was when Alexio placed a paw-like hand on Ryliner's shoulder. "You know, it would be unfortunate if something happened to your new guild. After all, I could easily afford to arm all of -" The tiger was forced to stop then and there.

"And it would be unfortunate if my ax, which is just resting between your legs, was suddenly jerked upwards, liberating your family jewels from your body, to say nothing about actual jewels."

Ryliner turned, and saw the ax that was set right between Alexio's legs. It was HUGE! The tiger was having difficulty standing still.

"What do you want?" the tiger asked.

"Let's start with your money, and work up from there."

That was when Ryliner looked behind Alexio. Then, he looked down. He'd been expecting a dwarf by the size of the ax, but, he wasn't expecting what he saw. "Um, do you have a permit for that ax?"

"Yeah, and a highwayperson license as well, in case you're curious," the person said.

"No offence, but, aren't you a little short to be a highwayperson?" Ryliner asked.

"And, what does your brother do for a living?" Ryliner asked.

"He's a wagonguard," said Bigjim. "It's a good business, me and him have - I rob them, and he protects them. We tend to work things out in advance, and even entertain the passengers, especially since they have to figure out, after a fight, who is the thief, and who is the guard - reduced fee if right, double fee if wrong."

"Excuse me."

Ryliner turned his head.

"Over here."

Ryliner turned his head again.

"In front of you!"

Ryliner looked again. He found himself looking at a face that was so unremarkable, he'd forget what it looked like half a block away. "What do you want?"

"How about both of them?" suggested a familiar voice.

Ryliner turned, and saw Rutabaga looking at them. "Commander?"

The Commander of the Guards stepped forward. "It would be an interesting prospect; Can the Goddess of War and the God of Substitutes work together in a Newly-Formed Guild? It would be interesting."

"It's never been done," said Serenabelle. "Two Gods being Honored by one group; it's impossible."

"It is claimed to be such because it has never been tried before," said Rutabaga. "Yet, a lot of gods share the temples here in the city. Why can't you do that for a Guild?"

"Because Temples, by and large, are usually religious, and for the most part, Gods and Goddesses don't have to share worshipers," said Substituto. "A Guild is more personal."

"I doubt the members of the Guild plan on worshiping you," said Rutabaga. "Either of you. Why don't you two try it out for the thirty days, and you can use it as Future Precedent as to why having two or more Gods Patronizing a Guild can work, or not work?"

The God and Goddess looked at each other.

1253.content:
Wiggins Wet, a.k.a. Johnathan Rich, among other names, was what one would call a con artist, who was the sort that could turn an old pale nag into a young black filly, and sell it for more than what it was really worth. He could sell the same bridge, thrice, within the hour, to three different people. He could convince bank tellers to give him money, for a blank sheet of paper. He was clever. Then, he came to Big Fat Pig City, and attempted to ply his trade. He was successful, at first. Then, he got caught. Luckily for him, it was by one of the City Guard, who merely arrested him for fraud, and not the Thieves Guild, who would have broken his arms and legs, before hanging him. As it was, Johnathan Rich had found himself with a rope around his neck, for his crimes which totaled over a hundred thousand in fraud, and there was a good crowd there to watch Justice Being Done. Johnathan tried to claim that there were worse people out there, who deserved to be hung instead of him. The hangman claimed that while this was true, they were not wearing the rope around their neck, put the hood over his head, and pulled the lever, and thus, Johnathan was executed.... or so it seemed. Within the hour, Wiggins found himself before the Tyrant, and the Commander. The Tyrant informed Wiggins that there were indeed people worse than him who deserved to be hung, and, unless he wished to be on the wrong end of a rope, for real this time, it would be in his best interests to locate these people, so that justice could be done. Coincidentally, there was a slot open for the division that investigated such crime, and that Commander Rutabaga was interested in taking on Wiggins Wet as a guard, although Wiggins didn't know how the Tyrant had found out about his real name.

William Scarlet O'Hara - a member of the Highwayman's Guild from the mountainous area of VunderVuld, William was part of the group that collected the tolls on the roads, as well as fixed them, and went after those who illegally robbed travelers, and who didn't give a fair share to the vampire and werewolf lords of the area, and thus would send these non-guildsmen to the lords and ladies of the land for punishment, which consisted of loud screaming, especially when they found out that they wouldn't be drained of blood, or torn to pieces, but would be instead forced to do hard labor mucking out the livestock pens, among other things. However, William grew tired of the mountains, and wished to see the city. He was given a good recommendation by both the Highwayman Guild, and the Vampire Lord, as well as a Werewolf Lady, and thus, William joined the Big Fat Pig City Guard.

12531.content:
"You have been found GUILTY!!!!!!"

"NOOO!!!!!" Wiggins screamed as the noose appeared around his neck, and the trapdoor opened. He continued to scream as the rope tightened around his neck. "It's only a dream! It has to be a dream! It's got to-"

He heard a pounding, and suddenly, the scaffolding vanished, as his eyes opened, and his bed and blankets appeared before them.

The door to his bedroom opened, and Wiggins found himself looking at a lovely-looking woman. Well, she would have been a lovely looking woman, save for those glasses, that mangy-looking hair, that flat chest, and the fact that she lack a certain hourglass-like shape. Of course, she was lovely if the last thing you just saw was a rope around your neck! But, the worst thing of it all was this - she was a stinking werewolf!

Wiggins had been blessed with a forgettable face - more than once his mother had to come back to the school because she had picked up a different child, instead of him. He could blend in a crowd, even if he was right in front of it. His victims could barely remember his features - between twenty and forty years of age, normal nose, light brown-blond hair, brown-green eyes, average height - just average, really. But a werewolf, that was different - each person had a smell to them. You could be in a crowd of a thousand people, and they'd still pick you out, so long as they had your scent!

Wiggins looked at the bitch - he could rightly call her one - and said, "Mind leaving me alone?"

"Depends," she said. She began to search the room. "I smelled fear coming from this room, and I heard you scream."

Wiggins groaned. "It was just a nightmare, dog-breath."

Too late! he remembered.

She was on him quickly, her jaws on his neck, having shifted into that middle form that some werewolves could hold onto, without going from man to wolf, or wolf to man, all the way. Just a little bit of pressure, that was all it would take, and he wouldn't need to worry about rope.

"Alright!" he gasped out. "I won't say it again!"

She growled, and let go of him. "I'm getting tired of doing that. One of these days, Wiggins Wet, I won't hold back."

"I think the Commander would be upset if you did that," Wiggins said, rubbing the area her teeth had been at.

"Given that you are Legally Dead, at least as Johnathan Rich, I don't think he'd complain too much," the werewolf said. "Besides, you know my name - Maria Whitefoot."

Wiggins looked down at her paw-like feet - they were black. However, it was a bad time for him to point this fact out, so he kept his mouth shut.

"So, let me guess," said Maria. "Was it the one about the rope around your neck? Or was it the one where I crushed your skull with my feet?"

"Rope around my neck," said Wiggins.

"Once you've been hung, it can be hard to forget the feeling of the rope around your neck," said Maria, as she shifted back into her human form.

"It's also pretty hard to forget the time you caught me when I tried to escape from this mess," said Wiggins. "There I was, enjoying a nice rest, as Jerry Stodgins, when you broke into that inn, dragged me from my bed, tossed me out the window, and decided to step on my head, shoving my face into a pile of horse apples!"

Maria looked at him, her eyes colder than ice. "You shouldn't have tried to do a runner. You should have just accepted the job, or, better yet, have been honest to begin with!"

Wiggins looked right back. However, he had to look away. He knew exactly what she was. The Official Story was that Maria was his secretary as he investigated accounts of those with suspicious money habits. The True Story, at least to those who could recognize a werewolf-in-human-form, was that she was his bodyguard. However, the Real Story was this - she was his Executioner if he stepped out of line - well, she hadn't said this, but during the trip back to the city, she bought an old troublesome billy goat from a farmer, for a good price, and then, when they were a ways away from everyone else, he watched her kill it, and then eat it. She didn't need to tell him anything else about the reason she was with him. She was always there, never far from his side. Granted, it made things easy when he had to bring a Plus One, and needed to deal with those who employed muscle, not to mention that time in the alley when someone tried kill him, but he knew that she was the one keeping him on a leash.

Wiggins then looked over at a timepiece he had, and decided that it was time to.....

13.content:
So, a female Human Guard - let's start with some options:

Sally Butcher: 18 years old, but is slim enough, and flat-chested enough to pass as a slightly short, and narrow man, and thus had signed up as John Smith - however, she was easily found out by Rutabaga, as you can't fool a werewolf's nose. Needless to say, the Quartermaster was filled with relief, as there was yet another ten John Smiths on the force, and finding out that one was really Sally Butcher made things easier on Pay Day. Coming from a family of Butchers, hence the family name, her father wanted her to marry a wealthy husband, but she wanted none of that. New to the job, Sally has her work cut out for her.

Fiona Nightshade: 27 years old. Fiona was once an Assassin, that's with a Capital A, who was skilled with poisons, and other toxins, plus other weapons. She was soon given a contract - Rutabaga Copperfindersson. Things did not turn out according to plan, in a number of ways. While she knew what the penalty for failure tended to be where the werewolf was concerned, it seems that someone else had hired a non-Assassin assassin to try to kill the Commander. Needless to say, the Assassins' Guild doesn't approve of such things, and thus, Fiona went after the non-Assassin assassin, and, while she managed to kill him, she was fatally wounded, and would have died had Rutabaga not located her, and taken her to a good Healer. When she recovered enough to go after the werewolf, she found herself in a predicament that prevented her from killing the one that had saved her life, and thus, dropped her weapon, and allowed the werewolf to punish her - of course, he took it relatively easy on her, as she was still recovering from her injuries. While she still does the occasional Contract Job, Fiona soon joined the Guard, partially in gratitude, and partially to keep an eye on the Commander for the Assassins.

Lora Slasher: 30 years old. Lora is a Monster Slayer, a job similar to being an Assassin, but for targeting Non-Humans instead. That being said, there's plenty of risks to the job. After all, bring down a renegade dragon, and folks consider you a Hero - kill an Innocent dragon however, who was obeying the law, and you won't be able to get out of town fast enough before the dragon's family gets their Justifiable Revenge, and burns you to ashes. Of course, despite being a Monster Slayer, Lora has plenty of Non-Human friends, and the occasional tryst with them. That being said, while being a Slayer can be highly rewarding, it isn't often she gets a Contract, and thus took to being a Guard to pay the bills.

Yokin Onaka - 25 years old. A foreigner from a foreign land called Eastrimland (in the Big Fat Pig language), Yokin had been captured and sold into Slavery, and was to be sold as a Sex Slave, along with a number of other foreign women from all over, and a number of men who were to be used for Labor. Slight problem - seems that Slavery is Illegal in the Big Fat Pig City area, and the Slave Trader was forced to give up his goods, or be executed for certain crimes, like Tax Evasion, and Failure to Pay Workers, and Kidnapping People for Forced Labor, Kidnapping People for Forced Sex, and, most importantly, kicking a dog, a dog that was wearing a City Guard badge, a dog that was really a werewolf, a werewolf who turned out to be Rutabaga Copperfinderson, who was just out for a walk and it's really a bad idea to kick a Guard that's just out for a walk, as he might arrest you for Assaulting a Guard! Needless to say, while the other slaves were found places to stay at, in areas where folks spoke and understood them, until they could either go back home or found a place to stay on at, Yokin was so foreign, there was no one who understood her, so Rutabaga let her stay at the Station, where it turns out that Yokin was a really good cook, and given that good cooks were in short supply, Rutabaga hired her on. Eventually, Yokin learned the language, and asked to become a Guard, where it was discovered she was a natural with unarmed combat, enough to the point that even the most muscular and well-armed thugs tend to surrender upon seeing her - if they are smart. Those that aren't smart, soon learn to surrender.
13.title: Female Human Guard

choices: She meets up with a fellow Guard
She hears a bell start ringing
She gets grabbed from behind, and dragged into an alley
131.content:
Sally breathed a sigh of relief after the Commander left. Bad news was, he'd figured out that she was a woman and not a man. Good news was, he hadn't fired her, and had told her in no uncertain terms that he'd had no issue with her being a woman, so long as she did the job. Of course, she was informed to notify the Quartermaster of her real identity, which would be a relief to him as there was already ten John Smiths on the payroll, and it would make things easier to know that one was really a Sally Butcher.

She then started to walk down the street that was part of her patrol route. It was an eight hour shift, from ten at night until six in the morning. Also, it was her first night on the job, and she hadn't much training with her weapon, a truncheon, a club that she was only allowed to use against a criminal's arms or legs, or tail, in order to disable them. She also had a knife, but that was only for cutting rope, or meat. She did have a metal breastplate, and backplate, and a helmet that, in addition to help protect against head wounds, also helped to keep the sun and rain out of her eyes, not to mention leather greaves and the like to protect her legs, however, her first defense, after foiling whatever crime she had disrupted, hopefully allowing the victim time to run away, was to run away herself. She didn't like that idea, but as the instructor pointed out, she and the other new recruits didn't know the first thing about street fighting, unless they were raised on the streets, and the important thing was to get to a place where help could easily be found, like the local taverns frequented by other City Guards, Licensed Thieves, Official Assassins, Legal Monster Slayers, Powerful Mages, and others who might make a would-be attacker decide to back off. It was one thing to attack a lone Guard, but it was suicide to attack twenty people trying to enjoy a drink. The only other things she had on her were her rations, and a bell, which she was to ring if there was an emergency, or if someone was trying to kill her. The idea was that is someone heard it, they'd come to investigate, giving a would-be attacker an additional twenty people to have to deal with. In in practice, this would give Sally a number of allies to help her out, in reality though, being confronted by over a dozen Guards usually caused criminals to run away themselves.

That was when Sally heard the rumble. She groaned. Her first night on patrol, and it was going to rain. Luckily, among the outfit she wore was a hooded cloak. It was brown in color, and decent protection against the elements. She put her pack down, got it out, and put it on just as the drops started to fall. She put her pack back on, and resumed walking.
131.title: Sally Butcher - New Guard

choices: "I got in trouble over a woman."
1311.content:
Annoyingly, the rain continued to fall, and it fell hard. Sally soon located an alley that was mostly out of the wind, and she got under an eaves, which helped her stay mostly dry. She thought that she was alone, until she heard a voice speak up.

"Got any smokes?" The voice was male.

"Um, no," she said, deepening her voice out of instinct. "Father always said it was a terrible habit."

"Cut the fake man voice," the person said. "It annoys me when people do that stuff."

"How do you know?" Sally asked.

"Work the job a few years, and you'll hear a lot of people use fake voices, especially those who try to hide their gender or their nationality," the person said. "Besides, I saw the Commander talk to you."

"I didn't know that anyone was listening," said Sally.

"There's always someone listening," the person said. "By now, most every Guard knows that you're a young woman, and that your real name is Sally Butcher. That being said, most will wait until you are ready to tell them yourself. There are no secrets among the Guard, but we are smart enough to respect Privacy."

Sally turned her head, and saw what looked to be a young man, looking at her. He seemed to be in his mid twenties, if that. Still, one couldn't always tell, especially in the cases of human-looking Undead. "So, what's your name?"

"Gareth," the man said. "And if you want to know what I'm doing out here in the rain, ......"
1311.title: She meets up with a fellow Guard

choices: "Catching my breath before taking flight again."
"Looking for an open window with a red ribbon hanging from it for a Meal."

13111.content:
"I'm a vampire."

Sally looked at him, and saw the signs, especially the eyes, which had the look of a predator, looking at a potential meal. She looked out into the rain, wondering if it would be a good idea to resume her patrol.

"You're safe with me," said Gareth. "I don't bite, much."

"That doesn't fulfill me with confidence," said Sally.

"I'd get in big trouble if I bit someone without their permission," said Gareth. "The person wouldn't like it, their father wouldn't like it, the law-biding vampires wouldn't like it, the Monster Slayers wouldn't like it, and finally, the Commander wouldn't like it, and no one wants to make him upset."

"He's a werewolf would be why," said Sally.

"Actually, if he was any other werewolf, I could probably take him," said Gareth. "The thing about the Commander is this, he has no issues about self-control. There has only been one time I've seen him lose it, and that was when someone raped, and murdered, this rookie, about three years ago. He hunted this guy down, and tore him apart, force-feeding him parts of his own body. It was probably a relief when he did die, but they had to cart his body out to the Hangman, for besides his head, that was all that was left attached, and even his eyes and tongue has been removed and forced down the guy's throat. Left the ears alone though, so that the Commander could say the guard's name, just as the Hangman pulled the lever."

"He's that protective?" Sally asked.

"At worst, most muggers are just going to strip you of your gear, and maybe break a few bones, before knocking you out, or after they knock you out," said Gareth. "As for killing you, or raping you, most know better than that."

"So, what are you doing out here?" Sally asked.

Gareth chuckled. "Simple really....."

Vampire comes in, pulls the flag in, has a nice little chat with you, bites you on the wrist, or some such place, has about half a cup, puts a bandage on the wound, pays an agreed upon amount, and leaves. Then, in about three months, you can hang the flag out again."

"I suppose that makes sense," said Sally. "Keeps the Monster Slayers off your back."

"Yes, although I look for those who also fly a gold star on their flags," said Gareth. "It means they've reserved themselves for a Guard."

"And, I suppose you're looking for one of those?" Sally asked.

1311131.content:
"I paid a visit a little while ago," said Gareth. "There was a Seamstress who owed me a little favor, and was interested in trying out a kink she'd been wanting to try."

"What kind of favor?" Sally asked.

"Unlicensed thief tried to rob her, and wasn't being very nice about it," said Gareth. "I showed them the error of their ways, especially when they tried to stab me with a steel dagger."

"They tried to stab you?" Sally asked.

"They would have been better off using a wooden stake, but it still put a hole in the outfit I was wearing," said Gareth. "After all, I was going to a party with some of my friends, and I wasn't wearing any armor. Granted, it didn't kill me, but it was a silk dress shirt, and those aren't easy to repair, so I made sure he didn't try that again."

Sally gulped. "Did you kill him?"

"Well, it would have been justified, given what he'd just tried to do, but I settled for draining a few cups of blood out of him, to help me heal, and to make him lethargic enough to not try anything for a few days," said Gareth. "Of course, the guards responding to the screams recognized me, and were nice enough to take the fool away before the Thieves Guild showed up to take him themselves. As for the Seamstress, she knew a Needlewoman who could repair my shirt, and make it look like it was never damaged."

"So, she was grateful for this rescue?" Sally asked.

"Well, the visit was on the house," said Gareth.

"So, um, what was the kink?" Sally asked.

"Well, she wanted the whole Victim experience, as in the window is open, the vampire drifts in, sees a scantily-clad young woman laying bed, with no covers on, gets on top of her, vampire opens his mouth up to reveal his fangs, and bites her," said Gareth.
